title: == None seems to do 'is None' for the array instead of returning element-wise comparison
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yarikoptic/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yarikoptic/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yarikoptic/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yarikoptic', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yarikoptic/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/yarikoptic', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yarikoptic/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/39889?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yarikoptic/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yarikoptic/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yarikoptic/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'yarikoptic', 'type': u'User', 'id': 39889, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yarikoptic/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.core', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.core'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Needs%20decision', 'color': u'0b02e1', 'name': u'Needs decision'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20normal', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: normal'}]
body:
May be related to #1608 
I understand that None is quite different beast but since comparison to None is allowed, I do not see why "a == None" should just return False instead of returning a bool dtyped array with element-wise comparisons as it does for other types.  See below that it simply returns False while comparing to None array contains.

```
$> PYTHONPATH=$PWD/lib.linux-x86_64-3.3 python3 -c 'import numpy; a=numpy.array([1, None, "str"]); print([a==x for x in a])'  
[array([ True, False, False], dtype=bool), False, array([False, False,  True], dtype=bool)]

$> PYTHONPATH=$PWD/lib.linux-x86_64-2.7 python -c 'import numpy; a=numpy.array([1, None, "str"]); print([a==x for x in a])' 
[array([ True, False, False], dtype=bool), False, array([False, False,  True], dtype=bool)]
```

title: BUG: fix #3017 Inconsistency in indexing 0-d arrays with Ellipsis.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dimasad/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dimasad/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dimasad/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dimasad', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dimasad/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/dimasad', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dimasad/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/989045?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dimasad/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dimasad/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dimasad/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'dimasad', 'type': u'User', 'id': 989045, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dimasad/followers'}
body:
As mentioned in Issue #3017, there were inconsistencies in the indexing and assignment of 0-d arrays:

    >>> import numpy as np
    >>> a = np.array(1)
    >>> a[...] = 2
    >>> a[...,]
    array(2)
    >>> a[...,] = 3
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
    IndexError: 0-d arrays can't be indexed.

The code which checked for special cases omitted this case (of `a[...,]`) so I included it as equivalent to `a[...]`.

Tested in python 2.7.3 and 3.2.3.

title: Fix issue #3743: Hash changed signature in Python 3.3
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/cgohlke', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/483428?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'cgohlke', 'type': u'User', 'id': 483428, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/followers'}
body:
As of Python 3.2 hash values are of type Py_hash_t. Previous versions use C long.

The changes should only affect win-amd64-py3.x, where `sizeof(Py_hash_t) != sizeof(long)`.

This fixes issue #3743. All tests pass on win-amd64-py3.3, win-amd64-py2.7, and win32-py2.7.

Needs backport to 1.8 and 1.7.

title: Hash changed signature in Python 3.3.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
```
ERROR: test_record_no_hash (test_multiarray.TestRecord)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
   File
"X:\Python33\lib\site-packages\numpy\core\tests\test_multiarray.py",
line 2464, in test_record_no_hash
     self.assertRaises(TypeError, hash, a[0])
   File "X:\Python33\lib\unittest\case.py", line 570, in assertRaises
     return context.handle('assertRaises', callableObj, args, kwargs)
   File "X:\Python33\lib\unittest\case.py", line 135, in handle
     callable_obj(*args, **kwargs)
   File "X:\Python33\lib\unittest\case.py", line 153, in __exit__
     self.obj_name))
TypeError: unhashable type: 'writeable void-scalar'
```

I [Christolph] could reproduce the weirdness outside the testsuite on 64 bit Python
3.2, 3.3 and 3.4. It looks like the interpreter gets corrupted.

It could be due to numpy 1.8 using a wrong signature for the hash
function [1] on win-amd64-py3.x. Since Python 3.2 the return value must
be of type `Py_hash_t` (defined as `Py_ssize_t`) [2], not `C long` as
for Python <= 3.1.

[1]
https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/numpy/core/src/multiarray/scalartypes.c.src#L3038
[2] http://docs.python.org/3.2/c-api/typeobj.html#PyTypeObject.tp_hash

title: Incorrect dtype for mask of MaskedArray
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwcraig/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwcraig/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwcraig/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwcraig', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwcraig/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mwcraig', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwcraig/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1147167?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwcraig/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwcraig/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwcraig/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mwcraig', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1147167, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwcraig/followers'}
body:
The dtype of the mask should, I think, be boolean, but isn't for structured arrays:

```
In [4]: a = numpy.ma.MaskedArray([(1,)], dtype=[('a', int)])

In [5]: print a
[(1,)]

In [6]: a.dtype
Out[6]: dtype([('a', '<i8')])

In [7]: a.mask.dtype
Out[7]: dtype([('a', '?')])
```

title: ENH: Speedup UFUNC_CHECK_STATUS by avoding heavy clear opition
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/arinkverma', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1556486?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'arinkverma', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1556486, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/followers'}
body: UFUNC_CHECK_STATUS is just single macro which do both checking clearing the error flags. It clear error flags every time after checking. We should avoid clear operation if not needed, as it is a bit expensive and take significant amount of time. The way numpy detect divide-by-zero, overflow, underflow, etc., is that before each ufunc loop it clear the FP error flags, and then after the ufunc loop we see if any have become set. And clear again. I have avoided clear if not needed to save time. Performance result is post on blog. http://www.arinkverma.in/2013/09/speedup-ufunccheckstatus-by-avoiding.html

title: test_scalarmath.TestBaseMath.test_blocked() triggers assertion failure
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/Arfrever', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/656294?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'Arfrever', 'type': u'User', 'id': 656294, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/followers'}
body:
test_scalarmath.TestBaseMath.test_blocked() triggers assertion failure in NumPy 1.8.0 beta1 and 1.8.0 beta 2.
This test does not exist in NumPy 1.7.1 and all tests of NumPy 1.7.1 pass.

Results of test suite of NumPy 1.8.0 beta 2:
```
...
test_unique_stable (test_regression.TestRegression) ... ok
Implemented in r2840 ... ok
test_void_copyswap (test_regression.TestRegression) ... ok
test_void_scalar_constructor (test_regression.TestRegression) ... ok
No ticket ... ok
Ticket #205 ... ok
Regression test for #1061. ... ok
Ticket #43 ... ok
Ticket #1733 ... ok
test_blocked (test_scalarmath.TestBaseMath) ... python2.7: numpy/core/src/umath/simd.inc.src:666: sse2_maximum_FLOAT: Assertion `npy_is_aligned(&ip[i], 16)' failed.
Aborted
```

title: may_share_memory fails when comparing arrays with datetime dtypes
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jtratner/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jtratner/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jtratner/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jtratner', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jtratner/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jtratner', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jtratner/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1598379?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jtratner/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jtratner/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jtratner/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jtratner', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1598379, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jtratner/followers'}
body:
e.g.

```python
import numpy as np
from datetime import datetime
dts = [datetime(2005, 1, i) for i in range(1, 11)]
arr = np.array(dts).astype('M8[ns]')
arr2 = arr - arr[::-1]
arr2 = arr2.astype('m8[ns]')
np.may_share_memory(arr, arr2)
```

Produces:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<console>", line 1, in <module>
  File "../lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/lib/utils.py", line 298, in may_share_memory
    a_low, a_high = byte_bounds(a)
  File "../lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/lib/utils.py", line 259, in byte_bounds
    bytes_a = int(ai['typestr'][2:])
ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: '8[ns]'
```

and here's my version:
```
>>> np.__version__
'1.7.1'
```

Sidenote: also fails just comparing
```python
np.may_share_memory(arr, arr[::-1])
```

title: MAINT: Make the qr raw mode test independent of the LAPACK library.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
The qr factorization is not unique and the values returned by the raw
mode may differ between LAPACK versions. Consequently, the results
cannot be checked against known values.

Closes #3703.

Needs a backport to 1.8.x.

title: MAINT: Refactor test_xerbla to hide printed error messages.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
Combine the xerbla override tests with the previous _is_xerbla_safe
decorator. The xerbla checks are then made in a forked process where the
outputs are closed so that if xerbla prints a message it does not
appear.

It would be nice to figure out a Windows version of this test.

Closes #3704.

title: Heap corruption when using np.cov and importing matplotlib.pyplot
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/idfah/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/idfah/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/idfah/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/idfah', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/idfah/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/idfah', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/idfah/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5430747?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/idfah/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/idfah/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/idfah/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'idfah', 'type': u'User', 'id': 5430747, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/idfah/followers'}
body:
I have a code snippet that causes python to abort with a double free or corruption error.  All the code really does is run np.cov in a loop and average the results.

Interestingly, I can only reproduce the error when several things are done together:

- matplotlib.pyplot must be imported
- the machine must be running the proprietary nvidia driver (I think)

I can't seem to reproduce the problem using gdb or valgrind either.  I know these kinds of bugs are difficult to troubleshoot but we have many machines with the same configuration and the only way a crash seems to be manifested is when using np.cov.  The graphics otherwise work and matplotlib otherwise appears to work.  Any insight into this would be much appreciated!

Here is the code:

```
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def avgCov(data):
    ndim = data[0].shape[1]
    acov = np.zeros((ndim,ndim))

    for c in data:
        acov += np.cov(c, rowvar=0)
    acov /= len(data)

    return acov

if __name__ == '__main__':
    for i in xrange(100):
        print i

        trueCov = [[1,-0.8],
                   [-0.8,1]]

        g1 = np.random.multivariate_normal((-1,-1), trueCov, 1000)
        g2 = np.random.multivariate_normal((0,0), trueCov, 600)
        g3 = np.random.multivariate_normal((1,1), trueCov, 800)

        acov = avgCov((g1, g2, g3))
```

Here is the error I get:

```
*** glibc detected *** python: double free or corruption (!prev): 0x0000000001447730 ***
======= Backtrace: =========
/usr/lib64/libc.so.6(+0x7cb3e)[0x7f0d4b187b3e]
/usr/lib64/libGL.so.1(+0xad4dc)[0x7f0d34b184dc]
======= Memory map: ========
00400000-00401000 r-xp 00000000 08:02 1454936                            /usr/bin/python2.7
00600000-00601000 r--p 00000000 08:02 1454936                            /usr/bin/python2.7
00601000-00602000 rw-p 00001000 08:02 1454936                            /usr/bin/python2.7
00c15000-0262f000 rw-p 00000000 00:00 0                                  [heap]
.............
```

It only crashes about 1/50 runs so I run it in a loop from bash:

```
while python ./python-crash.py
do
  echo '-------OK-------'
done
```

I have tried numpy 1.7.1 and the latest build checked out on August 22, 2013.  I am using matplotlib 1.2.0.

title: New behavior of np.ndindex in numpy 1.8.0dev
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/kwgoodman', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/299024?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'kwgoodman', 'type': u'User', 'id': 299024, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/followers'}
body:
The  bottleneck package gives four unit test failures (https://github.com/kwgoodman/bottleneck/issues/71) when run with numpy 1.8.0dev.

Two of the failures are due to this change in numpy  1.8.0dev:

```
In [1]: np.ndindex(*[0])
ValueError: Iteration of zero-sized operands is not enabled
```

whereas in numpy 1.7.1:

```
In [1]: np.ndindex(*[0])
Out[1]: <numpy.lib.index_tricks.ndindex at 0x325f310>
```

Was this change intentional?

title: ENH: new function proposal numpy.close
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/danieljfarrell', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/112847?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'danieljfarrell', 'type': u'User', 'id': 112847, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/followers'}
body:
I would like include a new function `numpy.close`. The behavior would be identical to `numpy.allclose` but would apply the equality test element by element and return an array of results. For example,

    def close(a, b, atol=1e-8, rtol=1e-5):
        return np.abs(a - b) <= (atol + rtol * np.abs(b))

This would be useful for filtering array of small values which appear due to numerical rounding. For example one use would be,

    # Comparison with a float
    data = np.array([1e-30, 1e-20, 1e-10, 0.1, 1, 10])
    data[np.where(np.close(data,0))] = 0.
    # np.array([0., 0., 0., 0.1, 1, 10])
    
    # Comparison with another array (same shape)
    data = np.array([1e-30, 1e-20, 1e-10, 0.1, 1, 10])
    data[np.where(np.close(data,np.zeros(data.shape)))] = 0.
    # np.array([0., 0., 0., 0.1, 1, 10])

This function would allow the comparison of floating point numbers within a tolerance and would be of much more practical use than the existing comparison function when doing numerical work. Moreover, `numpy.equal`, and `numpy.array_equal` apply the boolean equals operator (`==`) to each element without considering a tolerance. For numerical applications tolerance is very important.

Do you agree this is a good idea? If so I will prepare a pull request.

title: ENH: add support for Python 3.4 ast.NameConstant
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/cgohlke', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/483428?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'cgohlke', 'type': u'User', 'id': 483428, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/followers'}
body:
Python 3.4 created a "NameConstant AST class to represent None, True, and False literals" (http://docs.python.org/3.4/whatsnew/changelog.html). Numpy 1.8.0b2 fails 13 tests of the following kind. The suggested change fixes those test errors on win-amd64-py3.4a2. Consider backporting this to numpy 1.8.x.

```

title: ENH: High time consumption by PyUFunc_GetPyValues in ufunc_object.c
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/arinkverma', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1556486?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'arinkverma', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1556486, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/arinkverma/followers'}
body:
For every single operation calls, numpy has to extract value of buffersize, errormask and name to pack and build error object. These two functions, _extract_pyvals and PyUFunc_GetPyValues together use >12% of time. it take useless time because all this time is spent on to look up entries in a python dict, extract them, and convert them into C level data. Not once but doing that again and again on every operation. Here, I stash value to thread using TLS api and also avoiding building of errorObj again for same consecutive function. ## Improvement ### Before 
In [1]: import numpy as np

In [2]: x = np.asarray(1)

In [3]: timeit x+x
1000000 loops, best of 3: 1.67 us per loop

In [4]: x = np.asarray([1])

In [5]: timeit x+x
1000000 loops, best of 3: 1.76 us per loop
### After 
In [1]: import numpy as np

In [2]: x = np.asarray(1)

In [3]: timeit x+x
1000000 loops, best of 3: 1.56 us per loop

In [4]: x = np.asarray([1])

In [5]: timeit x+x
1000000 loops, best of 3: 1.69 us per loop

title: ENH: implement pairwise summation
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
pairwise summation has an average error of O(log(n)) instead of O(n) of
the regular summation.
It is implemented as summing pairs of small blocks of regulary summed
values in order to archive the same performance as the old sum.

An example of data which profits greatly is
d = np.ones(500000)
(d / 10.).sum() - d.size / 10.

An alternative to pairwise summation is kahan summation but in order to
have a low performance penalty one must unroll and vectorize it,
while pairwise summation has the same speed without any vectorization.
The better error bound of O(1) is negligible in many cases.

user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
@kkdd reports the following as a [commit comment] (https://github.com/numpy/numpy/commit/96ea318b10e31c405798a3f96d93b418d188969d#commitcomment-4001084)
```
It causes an error: "NameError: name 'tmp' is not defined".
I think the following modification is suitable:

 tmp = open(os.devnull, 'w')
 try:
     p = sp.Popen(["gcc", "-print-multiarch"], stdout=sp.PIPE, stderr=tmps)
   :
 finally:
     tmp.close()
```

body:
The any and all functions may return reals instead of booleans. The result was bool in 1.6.x
```
In [1]: x = np.random.rand(42364).astype(object)

In [2]: np.any(x)
Out[2]: 0.8834972689258551
```

body:
This bug resulted in using a long type when a long long was required,
resulting in numerous errors when numpy was compiled as 64 bits on
64 bit windows.

Needs a backport to 1.8.x.

title: np.meshgrid copy=False odd behavior
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ayr0/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ayr0/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ayr0/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ayr0', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ayr0/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ayr0', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ayr0/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/770238?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ayr0/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ayr0/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ayr0/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ayr0', 'type': u'User', 'id': 770238, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ayr0/followers'}
body:
np.meshgrid appears to have some odd behavior that I can't explain when copy=False
```
a = np.arange(1, 10)
b = np.arange(10, 20)
X, Y = np.meshgrid(a, b, copy=False)
```
X, Y should be views of a, b (which we can see by modifying a, b).
```
b[5] = 999
print Y
```
yields
```
[[ 10  10  10  10  10  10  10  10  10]
 [ 11  11  11  11  11  11  11  11  11]
 [ 12  12  12  12  12  12  12  12  12]
 [ 13  13  13  13  13  13  13  13  13]
 [ 14  14  14  14  14  14  14  14  14]
 [999 999 999 999 999 999 999 999 999]
 [ 16  16  16  16  16  16  16  16  16]
 [ 17  17  17  17  17  17  17  17  17]
 [ 18  18  18  18  18  18  18  18  18]
 [ 19  19  19  19  19  19  19  19  19]]
```
However, Y.base is b returns False.
Where is Y coming from if it is not a view of b?

Either somewhere, something was copied (which shouldn't happen because copy=False), or Y.base is not correct.

user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
This reverts commit de9f1c92d3ca0920bce915438f0406f587aa98db, reversing
changes made to d958dec676beeac218a118fac084fa8b14bc9171.

There is a change of behavior in conversion of signed to unsigned
PyLong that shows up on my machine. For some reason this did not show
up in the travisbot tests. This reverts the merge that led to this
problem until it can be sorted out. Error shows up as

numpy/core/arrayprint.py",
line 653, in __call__
    if _MININT < x < _MAXINT:
OverflowError: can't convert negative int to unsigned

title: Travisbot is missing some tests

title: numexpr.evaluate result type != numpy type on Windows
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/lpinner/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/lpinner/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/lpinner/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/lpinner', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/lpinner/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/lpinner', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/lpinner/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/4827816?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/lpinner/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/lpinner/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/lpinner/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'lpinner', 'type': u'User', 'id': 4827816, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/lpinner/followers'}
body:
Checking the type of an ndarray returned from a numexpr.evaluate(expression) against a numpy type fails on Windows.  

A ticket was raised against numexpr, but the maintainers suggested to raise it against numpy (https://code.google.com/p/numexpr/issues/detail?id=112).

To reproduce:
```python
import numpy as np, numexpr as ne

a = np.array([1], np.int32)
b=ne.evaluate('a')
print a.dtype.type,b.dtype.type
print a.dtype.type==b.dtype.type
print a.dtype.type==np.int32
print b.dtype.type==np.int32
```
Expected output:
```python
<type 'numpy.int32'> <type 'numpy.int32'>
True
True
True
```
Actual output:
```python
<type 'numpy.int32'> <type 'numpy.int32'>
False
True
False
```
Tested on Win 7 Enterprise with the following environment:

64bit python
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
Numexpr version:   2.1
NumPy version:     1.6.2
Python version:    2.7.2 (default, Jun 12 2011, 14:24:46) [MSC v.1500 64 bit (AMD64)]

VML available?     False
Detected cores:    4

32bit python

NumPy version:     1.6.2 (and 1.7.0)
Python version:    2.7.2 (default, Jun 12 2011, 15:08:59) [MSC v.1500 32 bit (Intel)]
AMD/Intel CPU?     True
VML available?     False
Detected cores:    4
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Tested on Win XP with the following environment:

title: why support for axis=(1,2,3), i.e. a tuple, is not documented?
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/saullocastro', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3889819?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'saullocastro', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3889819, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saullocastro/followers'}
body:
In NumPy 1.7.1 we have seen some answers in SO:

- http://stackoverflow.com/a/18357674/832621

- http://stackoverflow.com/a/18545281/832621

where they are suggesting to pass a tuple to the `axis` argument.

It does work but we cannot find where it is documented.

Do you have any plans to include this into the official documentation?

Thank you!

title: structured arrays with different byteorders do not compare
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mdboom', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/38294?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mdboom', 'type': u'User', 'id': 38294, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdboom/followers'}
body:
Equality comparisons don't work on structured arrays if they have different byteorders.  This seems to be inconsistent with what happens with non-structured arrays.  Should this be considered a bug?  If so, I'd be happy to take a crack at fixing it.

```
In [1]: import numpy as np

In [2]: x = np.array([5], dtype=">i8")

In [3]: y = np.array([5], dtype="<i8")

In [4]: x == y
Out[4]: array([ True], dtype=bool)

In [6]: x = np.array([(5,)], dtype=[('a', '>i8')])

In [7]: y = np.array([(5,)], dtype=[('a', '<i8')])

In [8]: x == y
Out[8]: False
```

title: BUG: arrays initialize to dtype object when multiplied by long.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andrewpchester/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andrewpchester/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andrewpchester/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andrewpchester', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andrewpchester/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/andrewpchester', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andrewpchester/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1744375?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andrewpchester/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andrewpchester/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andrewpchester/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'andrewpchester', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1744375, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/andrewpchester/followers'}
body:
When initializing a numpy array, I get strange behavior when I multiply it by a long int on the same line as it is created. This is in python version 3.2.3 and numpy version 1.6.1

Compare:
````
>>> BIG = 10000000000000000000000000000
>>> a = np.ones(1)*BIG
>>> a.dtype
dtype('object')
>>> a
array([1e+28], dtype=object)
````
to:
````
>>> b = np.ones(1)
>>> b*=BIG
>>> b.dtype
dtype('float64')
>>> b
array([  1.00000000e+28])
````

The second example is (presumably) the desired behavior, as silent conversion of the dtype of the array seems quite dangerous.

body:
Backport of partial fix for #3656.

Loosen some test requirements for np.dot. Because the 'F' order arrays are no longer copied, they no longer are likely to produce the same as the copied 'C' order arrays did due to different order of carrying out the arithmetic.

title: numpy/doc: Is an URL field possible for public facing APIs?
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/heiskr/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/heiskr/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/heiskr/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/heiskr', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/heiskr/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/heiskr', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/heiskr/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1221423?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/heiskr/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/heiskr/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/heiskr/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'heiskr', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1221423, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/heiskr/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20Documentation', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: Documentation'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Needs%20decision', 'color': u'0b02e1', 'name': u'Needs decision'}]
body:
I'm working on a project that is using

https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/doc/HOWTO_DOCUMENT.rst.txt

to document the controllers and such. It would be excellent if there as a URL section too for hosted, public facing APIs so people know what URLs they can hit. I thought about forking it, but I wonder if it would be useful to other projects as well? Not sure.

Feel free to close if this has already been addressed; I searched through the issues but didn't see anything related.

title: ENH: percentile function with additional parameters and vecorization
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jjhelmus/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jjhelmus/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jjhelmus/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jjhelmus', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jjhelmus/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jjhelmus', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jjhelmus/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1050278?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jjhelmus/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jjhelmus/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jjhelmus/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jjhelmus', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1050278, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jjhelmus/followers'}
body:
The percentile function was enhanced by adding limit and interpolation
parameters to give it similar functionality to SciPy's stats.scoreatpercentile
function.  In addition the function was vecorized along q and rewritten to
use the partition method for better performance.

This pull request is in replacement of PR #2970

body:
Because neither poly1d nor the Polynomial package polynomial classes are
immutable, hence not reliably hashable, they should signal that by
setting __hash__ = None. This also fixes the warning

Overriding __eq__ blocks inheritance of __hash__ in 3.x

that is given when the command `python2.7 -3 -c"import numpy"` is run.

title: FIX: unchecked mallocs and various other things
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/larsmans', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/335383?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'larsmans', 'type': u'User', 'id': 335383, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/larsmans/followers'}
body:
Follow-up to #3653: some more C fixes and cleanup. Highlight is the fixing of a few unchecked mallocs; there are more of these in the codebase. Also, I removed some casts of the form

    char *p = (char *)malloc(n);

which are useless, since C will convert a `void*` to any other pointer automatically; this casting style is more likely to [hide bugs](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1565496/specifically-whats-dangerous-about-casting-the-result-of-malloc) than to fix them.

(For the automatic conversion, witness the casts that I removed in `multiarraymodule.c`: some functions were casting `void*` to `char*`, only to return `void*`.)

title: numpy.gradient enhancement to use second order accurate difference over the full domain
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/danieljfarrell', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/112847?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'danieljfarrell', 'type': u'User', 'id': 112847, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/followers'}
body:
This is a pull request related to issue https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/3603 .

The changes to the gradient function work as expected for float and int datatypes, and improve the accuracy of the derivative. However, the function can not yet deal with date and time datatypes.

Please run test_function_base.py tests or see the build errors viewing the Travis CI below.

**Could you suggest how to improve the function so that it works with date and time dtypes?** I don't understand this part of the gradient function so I don't know how to filter them out.

body:
`numpy.pad` still seems to break for pad widths of zero. I noticed this commit c6ce294f6feeebcdf67b238564c770387be933a5 but the problem seems to persist: 


>>> print np.__version__
1.9.0.dev-202e78d

>>> a = np.arange(12).reshape(3,4)

>>> np.pad(a,((1,2),(2,1)), mode='constant')    # case 1 ok

>>> np.pad(a,((0,0),(2,1)), mode='constant')    # case 2 breaks
Traceback: 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
 in ()
----> 1 np.pad(a, pad, mode='constant', constant_values=99)

/home/alistair/.venvs/pylab_base/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/lib/arraypad.pyc in pad(array, pad_width, mode, **kwargs)
   1280 
   1281     narray = np.array(array)
-> 1282     pad_width = _validate_lengths(narray, pad_width)
   1283 
   1284     allowedkwargs = {

/home/alistair/.venvs/pylab_base/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/lib/arraypad.pyc in _validate_lengths(narray, number_elements)
   1083         if (chk[0] < 0) or (chk[1] < 0):
   1084             fmt = "%s cannot contain negative values."
-> 1085             raise ValueError(fmt % (number_elements,))
   1086     return normshp
   1087 

ValueError: ((0, 0), (2, 1)) cannot contain negative values.
Case 2 works fine in 1.7.1

title: BUG: In Ellipsis matrix indexing.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/cowlicks', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/598099?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'cowlicks', 'type': u'User', 'id': 598099, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cowlicks/followers'}
body:
I think this is a bug. Otherwise it could that I don't understand how ellipses ares supposed to behave.
If we have:
```python
In [97]: c
Out[97]: 
matrix([[1, 2, 2, 1, 2],
        [3, 2, 2, 2, 2],
        [0, 1, 2, 0, 0],
        [3, 3, 0, 1, 0],
        [3, 0, 2, 2, 3]])
```
Indexing with some `Ellipsis`'s give weird results. The first example makes sense:

```python
In [98]: c[..., 1]
Out[98]: 
matrix([[2],
        [2],
        [1],
        [3],
        [0]])
```
But I don't understand why the shape is different here:
```python
In[99]: c[:, ..., 1]
Out[99]: matrix([[2, 2, 1, 3, 0]])
```

body:
These fail but shouldn't.
```python

In [77]: Ellipsis in (np.array([1, 2, 3]),)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-77-f1700c2dec87> in <module>()
----> 1 Ellipsis in (np.array([1, 2, 3]),)

ValueError: The truth value of an array with more than one element is ambiguous. Use a.any() or a.all()


In [74]: Ellipsis in (1, np.array([1, 2, 3]), ...)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-74-5b3e93a10456> in <module>()
----> 1 Ellipsis in (1, np.array([1, 2, 3]), ...)

ValueError: The truth value of an array with more than one element is ambiguous. Use a.any() or a.all()

```
But these work. Which seems odd since the other case is broken.
```python 

In [72]: Ellipsis in np.array([1, 2, 3])
Out[72]: False

In [73]: Ellipsis is np.array([1, 2, 3])
Out[73]: False
```

title: Is this an error in numpy doc on numpy.polyfit?
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yw5aj/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yw5aj/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yw5aj/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yw5aj', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yw5aj/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/yw5aj', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yw5aj/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3477741?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yw5aj/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yw5aj/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yw5aj/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'yw5aj', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3477741, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/yw5aj/followers'}
body:
On page http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.polyfit.html

It first stated:
Fit a polynomial p(x) = p[0] * x**deg + ... + p[deg] of degree deg to points (x, y). 
Returns a vector of coefficients p that minimises the squared error.

And then later, it said:
in the equations:
x[0]**n * p[n] + ... + x[0] * p[1] + p[0] = y[0]
x[1]**n * p[n] + ... + x[1] * p[1] + p[0] = y[1]
...
x[k]**n * p[n] + ... + x[k] * p[1] + p[0] = y[k]

Should the latter be consistent with the former, at least to reduce confusion? Instead of going from p[n] to p[0], it should be p[0] to p[n].

Thanks!

body:
Move generation of polynomial classes to build time

* Improve Numpy package import time by moving auto-generation of
  polynomial classes to build time. See Github issue
  https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/634 and original pull request
  discussion at https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/334

user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
The code was intended to check refcounting, and indeed, exposed a long
standing bug by failing, which is why it was commented out. That bug is
now fixed and tested by gh-3631, so the commented out code could
theoretically be made to work, but that requires enough del this and del
the other that I think it is too fragile to keep. So delete it.

title: MAINT: Move NPY_BEGIN_THREADS_DEF to end of declarations.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
The is an ';' at the end of the macro definition. When used and followed
by another ';', gcc thinks a statement has been made. An empty
statement, but still a statement. This causes compilation failure with
Python 3.4a.

The ';' should probably be removed, but that was undone in 1.7 to
maintain backward compatibility.

title: BUG: MapIter leaked itself and arr and index objects
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
MapIterBind incorrectly behaved when failing, cleaning up most
but not everything. The callers have to decref the mapiter
object. Which basically means that MapIterBind does not even
have to decref the new fields (they are decrefed in the
mapiter dealloc anyway).

Note that trying to add tests checking the refcounting
failed, but the tests seem to fail at least in many cases
not because of the indexing.

Closes gh-3589

-

OK, I just commented the failing tests (I think). It would be nice to track down, but correctly decrefing mapiter is better then nothing for 1.8. and I certainly do not have time to even try finding out where it might be going bad in the next weeks.

title: View of rows as strings: regression in 1.7 (dtype cast)
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/deeplycloudy/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/deeplycloudy/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/deeplycloudy/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/deeplycloudy', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/deeplycloudy/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/deeplycloudy', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/deeplycloudy/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1325771?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/deeplycloudy/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/deeplycloudy/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/deeplycloudy/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'deeplycloudy', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1325771, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/deeplycloudy/followers'}
body:
The following code, based on (1) and used in (2), works in numpy 1.6 and fails in numpy 1.7 and 1.8.0.dev-3bc6b96. It uses a casts a 2D integer array to a string view of the rows. It use it to determine unique vectors in an array. 
import numpy as np
print np.__version__

a=np.arange(12).reshape(4,3)
a[2]=(3,4,5)
print a

# This line is ok on np 1.6.1, error on np 1.7.1 is
# "TypeError: data type S24S24S24S24 not understood on numpy 1.7.1"
unq, unq_idx = np.unique(a.view(
                    ('S%d'%(a.itemsize*a.shape[1]))*a.shape[0]), 
                    return_index=True)

print unq, unq_idx
print a[unq_idx,:]
(1) http://www.mail-archive.com/numpy-discussion@scipy.org/msg04176.html (2) https://bitbucket.org/deeplycloudy/lmatools/src/aa52817e41e796e185f70cdb86ea1659859ab7d4/density_tools.py Previously mentioned in issue #3159 and pull request #3170.

title: BUG: Use io.open instead of open for compatibility.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
The recent Python 3 fix adding encoding="utf-8" to the open function
fails on Python 2 because the encoding keyword is not defined. The
solution is to use io.open, which is available for Python 2.6 and 2.7
and is an alias for open when Python >= 3.0. It is reputed to be slow
when running in 2.6, but that should not be a problem.

title: Improve ``np.take`` to work correctly when indices=boolean_array
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/venthur/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/venthur/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/venthur/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/venthur', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/venthur/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/venthur', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/venthur/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/128459?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/venthur/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/venthur/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/venthur/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'venthur', 'type': u'User', 'id': 128459, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/venthur/followers'}
body:
Hi,

When you pass a boolean array as ``indices`` to ``np.take`` you probably want to do boolean indexing (or masking). ``np.take`` however converts the boolean array into an array of zeros and ones and uses that as indexing array. Which is probably not what the user expected.

This is very confusing if not wrong. Confusing, because most users probably expect ``np.take`` to behave like ``__getitem__`` to accept index- or boolean arrays. And if that is not the case one should at least put the analogous method ``np.compress`` which works like ``np.take`` just with boolean arrays in the `See Also`-Section of ``np.take``.

title: Problem with imports in polynomial.polynomial docstring examples
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Juanlu001/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Juanlu001/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Juanlu001/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Juanlu001', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Juanlu001/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/Juanlu001', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Juanlu001/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/316517?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Juanlu001/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Juanlu001/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Juanlu001/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'Juanlu001', 'type': u'User', 'id': 316517, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Juanlu001/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20Documentation', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: Documentation'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.polynomial', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.polynomial'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}]
body:
In most of the functions in polynomial.polynomial you can read this line:

    >>> from numpy import polynomial as P

and then:

    >>> P.polyline(1,-1)
    >>> sum = P.polyadd(c1,c2); sum
    >>> P.polysub(c1,c2)
    >>> P.polyder(c) # (d/dx)(c) = 2 + 6x + 12x**2
    [...]

https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/v1.7.1/numpy/polynomial/polynomial.py

but *all* these lines fail because all those members are part of the polynomial module in the polynomial package. It should be therefore like:

    >>> P.polynomial.polyline(1,-1)
    >>> sum = P.polynomial.polyadd(c1,c2); sum
    >>> P.polynomial.polysub(c1,c2)
    >>> P.polynomial.polyder(c) # (d/dx)(c) = 2 + 6x + 12x**2
    [...]

Nevertheless, this looks like a bit too long for me and I wonder if it would be possible to import some convenience functions using power series polynomials (polynomial.polyfit and things like that) directly into the polynomial package namespace.

I wrote "polynomial" too many times already :)

title: frombuffer returns incorrect result with non-contiguous input array
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/joshayers/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/joshayers/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/joshayers/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/joshayers', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/joshayers/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/joshayers', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/joshayers/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/831565?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/joshayers/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/joshayers/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/joshayers/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'joshayers', 'type': u'User', 'id': 831565, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/joshayers/followers'}
body:
For non-contiguous input arrays, numpy.frombuffer ignores the stride the array.  The output has the correct length, but it assumes a stride equal to the item size.

The following commands were tested under Numpy 1.7.1 and Python 3.3.

a = numpy.array([0, 1, 2, 3], dtype='i8')
numpy.frombuffer(a[0:4:2], dtype='i4')

The output is [0, 0, 1, 0], but was expected to be [0, 1, 2, 3].

I also tested under NumPy 1.6.1 and Python 2.7.  For that configuration an exception was raised - "TypeError: expected a single-segment buffer object".

title: Bugfix: Regression when filling struct from tuple
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwiebe/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwiebe/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwiebe/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwiebe', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwiebe/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mwiebe', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwiebe/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/399551?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwiebe/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwiebe/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwiebe/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mwiebe', 'type': u'User', 'id': 399551, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwiebe/followers'}
body:
Here's a bugfix for functionality which regressed from 1.6 -> 1.7, calling x.fill() with a tuple. Should have filed this PR sooner, sorry!

```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> np.__version__
'1.6.2'
>>> x = np.zeros(2, dtype=[('a', 'f8'), ('b', 'i4')])
>>> x.fill((3.5, -2))
>>> x
array([(3.5, -2), (3.5, -2)],
      dtype=[('a', '<f8'), ('b', '<i4')])
      
>>> import numpy as np
>>> np.__version__
'1.7.1'
>>> x = np.zeros(2, dtype=[('a', 'f8'), ('b', 'i4')])
>>> x.fill((3.5, -2))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ValueError: Input object to FillWithScalar is not a scalar
```

title: Improving numpy.gradient to be second order accurate over the full domain
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/danieljfarrell', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/112847?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'danieljfarrell', 'type': u'User', 'id': 112847, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/danieljfarrell/followers'}
body:
Currently `gradient` uses a second order accurate central finite difference for interior elements, and a first order accurate forward (backwards) finite difference for the first (last) element. This causes an issue at the ends of the domain where the gradient appears to jump.

By including an additional mesh point of the first and last elements (i.e. a second order one sided finite difference) it is possible to make numerical differential second order accurate over the whole domain.

For example. 

![second_order_accurate](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/112847/945162/7c153044-02f9-11e3-98ae-3d7e6433c07a.png)

The second order accurate finite difference were calculated as follows,

```python
def gradient_second_order(y, dx=1):
    """Returns second order accurate derivative of y using constant step size dx."""
    
    assert np.isscalar(dx), "dx must be a constant."
    
    dy = np.zeros_like(y)
    
    # Second order forward difference for first element
    dy[0] = -(3*y[0] - 4*y[1] + y[2]) / (2*dx)
    
    # Central difference interior elements
    dy[1:-1] = (y[2:] - y[0:-2])/(2*dx)
    
    # Backwards difference final element
    dy[-1] = (3*y[-1] - 4*y[-2] + y[-3]) / (2*dx)
    
    return dy
```
For more information on one sided finite difference approximations, the paper, ["One-sided finite-difference approximations suitable for use with Richardson extrapolation"](ftp://ftp.demec.ufpr.br/CFD/bibliografia/MER/Rahul_Bhattacharyya_2006.pdf) gives a nice review.

body:
In the Python interactive interpreter, running

    while condition:
        expression

spams the console with the result of `expression` each loop, not of `condition`.  This is misstated in the documentation.

body:
There is a need to add test case which ensure and maintain the behavior of integer. As per pr #3567, which speed up integer scalar's operations by avoiding the conversion of integer to NumPy Scalar. Test case --------- For np.int16 
a = np.array([2**15-1]], dtype=np.int16)
b = np.array([-2**15], dtype=np.int16)           
assert_equal(a,b-1)
For np.uint16 
a = np.array([2**16-1]], dtype=np.uint16)
b = np.array([0], dtype=np.uint16)           
assert_equal(a+1,b)

title: use PyDataMem_NEW_ZERO (calloc) for PyArray_Zeros
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
PyDataMem_NEW_ZERO uses calloc which will take advantage of the fact
that most operating systems provide already zero initialized memory
blocks on larger allocations.
Additionally this memory can be sparse (= mapped to a single zero page)
on some systems (e.g. linux) reducing memory usage of applications
using sparse arrays.

title: PyArray_MapIterBind leaks memory on failure
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
when run the test_indexing.py file leaks 9 MB of memory.
This seems to be due to PyArray_MapIterBind not dereferencing the full iterator on failure, nor its two callers doing so.
dereferencing it in the fail label fixes the leak and the testsuite still passes but I can't judge the side effects.
