title: BUG: field assignment in masked array did not reset mask; closes #2403
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/efiring', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/85125?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'efiring', 'type': u'User', 'id': 85125, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/followers'}
body:
The previous behavior when setting a field after indexing to
select an element was suitable for the hard mask case, but
not for the default soft mask.  In addition, the _hardmask
value was not being set at all in the mvoid instance.  With
this changeset, the _hardmask is passed in and __setitem__
takes it into account.

Backport of fb4edf7 from master to 1.7.x.

Conflicts:

	numpy/ma/core.py

title: BUG: field assignment in masked array did not reset mask; closes #2403

body:
The previous behavior when setting a field after indexing to
select an element was suitable for the hard mask case, but
not for the default soft mask.  In addition, the _hardmask
value was not being set at all in the mvoid instance.  With
this changeset, the _hardmask is passed in and __setitem__
takes it into account.

title: BUG: add __len__ method to ma.mvoid; closes #576
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/efiring', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/85125?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'efiring', 'type': u'User', 'id': 85125, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/efiring/followers'}
body:
A record selected from a structured ndarray by indexing is of type numpy.void.  Indexing a record from a structured masked array yields numpy.void if the mask is False, but numpy.ma.mvoid if the mask is True.  This PR adds the mvoid.__len__() method that was missing.  It merely calls the __len__() method on the _data attribute, which is of type numpy.void.

A test is included.

title: BUG: Revert "ENH: enable unaligned loads on x86"
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
This reverts commit aef286debfd11a62f1c337dea55624cee7fd4d9e.
x86 platform works with unaligned access but the compiler is allowed to assume
all data is aligned to its size by the C standard. This means it can vectorize
instructions peeling only by the size of the type, if the data is not aligned
to this size one ends up with data not correctly aligned for SSE instructions
(16 byte).
So this flag can only be enabled if autovectorization is disabled.

title: Regression: float64 and Python long int multiplication fails
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/pv', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/35046?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'pv', 'type': u'User', 'id': 35046, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/followers'}
body:
Multiplying float64 and Python long integers with large values fails on current Numpy master. This used to work (and works on 1.7.1).

On master at 65fe95ccc73:
```
Python 2.7.4 (default, Apr 19 2013, 18:28:01) 
>>> np.float64(1.0) * 123123123123123123123L
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for *: 'numpy.float64' and 'long'
```

Spotted in Scipy.

title: BUG: ma: ma.average didn't handle complex arrays correctly (issue gh-2684)
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/WarrenWeckesser', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/321463?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'WarrenWeckesser', 'type': u'User', 'id': 321463, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/followers'}
body:
The problem was the numerator in the calculation of the average was being cast to float.  This might have been to ensure that integer arrays were handled correctly, but now that the default behavior is true division, this is not necessary.

This closes issue gh-2684.

title: BUG: distutils: check Fortran ABI for BLAS libraries
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/pv', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/35046?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'pv', 'type': u'User', 'id': 35046, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/followers'}
body:
Make numpy.distutils to check that the BLAS libraries can actually be used from Fortran, with the currently active Fortran compiler configuration. Failing to check this can result to several commonly used functions such as SDOT, DDOT, ..., to either return invalid results or segfault when called from Fortran code.

The second commit also turns on `-ff2c` flag on OSX for gfortran, so that the default flags are compatible with Veclib/Accelerate. The other commit is independent of this. We can drop the OSX flag change, if it seems too risky (the ABI error message is informative and tells the user how to add `-ff2c` to the build flags).

Known occurrence of problems: Scipy's ARPACK routines currently **fail consistently** on OSX due to Fortran ABI mismatch. Scipy has some wrapper code that uses Veclib's C API instead of the Fortran API, but this is brittle and fails for a reason or another to work properly on OSX 10.7 and 10.8. Such wrappers are IMHO better left on the responsibility of whoever is doing the building rather than bundled by us.

Moreover, allowing numpy.distutils to give an incompatible flags+library info combination is a trap for 3rd party modules, whose authors may not be aware (and should not be requried to be!) of the Fortran ABI issues.

NOTE: this PR affects also Intel MKL which I think may have similar ABI issues, so also it should be tested. I don't yet know how far the consequences stretch in this direction, so feedback would be useful.

@cournape: heads up, this probably may affect Enthought's build rig

title: ENH: vectorize boolean logical &&, ||, abs and not
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
The code ensures the result is identical to a boolean operation even
though this might be unnecessary if bools are used correctly everywhere.
The overhead doesn't matter much as vectorizing single byte operations
hits the memory bandwidth limit very quickly.

Improves performance by about a factor of 5 to 10 depending on the cpu.
These operations currently can't be autovectorized by gcc 4.8.

body:
The documentation page has a broken link:

http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-dev/reference/generated/numpy.save.html?highlight=save#numpy.save

It says:

For a description of the .npy format, see format.

title: Unexpected return type of numpy.mean()
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/WarrenWeckesser', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/321463?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'WarrenWeckesser', 'type': u'User', 'id': 321463, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/followers'}
body:
The docstring for `numpy.mean` has this example that demonstrates the use of the `dtype` argument:

    >>> a = np.zeros((2, 512*512), dtype=np.float32)
    >>> a[0,:] = 1.0
    >>> a[1,:] = 0.1
    >>> m32 = np.mean(a)
    >>> m32
    0.546875
    >>> m64 = np.mean(a, dtype=np.float64)
    >>> m64
    0.55000000074505806

What is strange is that in the first case, even though the accumulator was 32 bit, the return value is 64 bit:

    >>> type(m32)
    <class 'numpy.float64'>

That's unexpected.  Why do the work in 32 bit, and then return a 64 bit result?

title: ENH: tell gcc to unroll strided copy loops
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
The strided copy loops profit a lot from unrolling as the number of
operations executed is in each iterations very small.
GCC needs to be told explicitly to do unrolling even on O3.

Unrolling is only profitable if the move can be done in a single
instruction, else the increased code size makes it slower, thus the flag
is only used for operations on element sizes less equal the native
pointer size.

Tested to improve performance of by 20-50% on intel core2duo, xeon
5xxx/7xxx and amd phenom x4.

title: Regression in 1.7.1 ctor.c setArrayFromSequence()
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/prossahl/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/prossahl/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/prossahl/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/prossahl', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/prossahl/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/prossahl', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/prossahl/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/4680320?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/prossahl/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/prossahl/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/prossahl/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'prossahl', 'type': u'User', 'id': 4680320, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/prossahl/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Easy%20Fix', 'color': u'02e10c', 'name': u'Easy Fix'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Regression', 'color': u'7F0000', 'name': u'Regression'}]
body:
setArrayFromSequence() returns error code 0 on error:

    >>> arr = np.array([[1,2,3],[4,5,6]])
    >>> arr[:,1] = [] # This blows up in 1.6.2, not in 1.7.1
    >>> arr[0,1]
    2
    >>> arr # Kaboom!

Here is the patch:

    diff -ur numpy-1.7.1_orig/numpy/core/src/multiarray/ctors.c numpy-1.7.1/numpy/core/src/multiarray/ctors.c
    --- numpy-1.7.1_orig/numpy/core/src/multiarray/ctors.c	2013-04-07 06:04:05.000000000 +0100
    +++ numpy-1.7.1/numpy/core/src/multiarray/ctors.c	2013-06-12 15:25:59.423961489 +0100
    @@ -383,7 +383,7 @@
                             int dim, npy_intp offset)
     {
         Py_ssize_t i, slen;
    -    int res = 0;
    +    int res = -1;
     
         /*
          * This code is to ensure that the sequence access below will
    diff -ur numpy-1.7.1_orig/numpy/core/tests/test_regression.py numpy-1.7.1/numpy/core/tests/test_regression.py
    --- numpy-1.7.1_orig/numpy/core/tests/test_regression.py	2013-04-07 06:04:05.000000000 +0100
    +++ numpy-1.7.1/numpy/core/tests/test_regression.py	2013-06-12 14:42:54.469727026 +0100
    @@ -1816,7 +1816,14 @@
                                   order='F')
             assert_array_equal(arr2, data_back)
     
    -
    +    def test_setArrayFromSequence_fails(self):
    +        # 1.6.2 passes this test, 1.7.1 fails
    +        arr = np.array([[1,2,3],[4,5,6]])
    +        try:
    +            arr[:,1] = []
    +        except ValueError:
    +            pass
    +        str(arr)
     
     
     if __name__ == "__main__":

title: PyArray_Transpose does not anticipate subclasses
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body: Transposing seems to be well defined for subclasses. However, the machinery does not anticipate the subclass doing anything fancy (it could in principle change the shape, ignoring that, it could force a copy). It is simply assumed that the subclass will not do anything about shape or data pointer as far as I can see. Probably anything it tries to do about shape will simply get overwritten in any case.

title: intent(in) breaks f2py -h for python 3 (UnboundLocalError in crackfortran.py)
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/chatcannon', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2848682?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'chatcannon', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2848682, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/chatcannon/followers'}
body:
```fortran
integer function breaksf2py(arg)
  integer, intent(in) :: arg

  breaksf2py = 2 * arg
end
```

Compiling with `f2py -m foo breaksf2py.f90` works fine, but `f2py -m foo -h foo.pyf breaksf2py.f90` gives the following error for python3 f2py (tested with 3.2 and 3.3) 
> Reading fortran codes...
>         Reading file 'breaksf2py.f90' (format:free)
> Post-processing...
>         Block: foo
>                         Block: breaksf2py
> Post-processing (stage 2)...
> Saving signatures to file "./foo.pyf"
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "/usr/bin/f2py-3.2", line 24, in <module>
>     main()
>   File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/site-packages/numpy/f2py/f2py2e.py", line 590, in main
>     run_main(sys.argv[1:])
>   File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/site-packages/numpy/f2py/f2py2e.py", line 361, in run_main
>     postlist=callcrackfortran(files,options)
>   File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/site-packages/numpy/f2py/f2py2e.py", line 286, in callcrackfortran
>     pyf=crackfortran.crack2fortran(postlist)
>   File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/site-packages/numpy/f2py/crackfortran.py", line 2749, in crack2fortran
>     pyf=crack2fortrangen(block)+'\n'
>   File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/site-packages/numpy/f2py/crackfortran.py", line 2517, in crack2fortrangen
>     ret=ret+crack2fortrangen(g,tab,as_interface=as_interface)
>   File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/site-packages/numpy/f2py/crackfortran.py", line 2561, in crack2fortrangen
>     vars=vars2fortran(block,block['vars'],argsl,tab+tabchar, as_interface=as_interface)
>   File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/site-packages/numpy/f2py/crackfortran.py", line 2711, in vars2fortran
>     lst = true_intent_list(vars[a])
>   File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/site-packages/numpy/f2py/crackfortran.py", line 2612, in true_intent_list
>     if c:
> UnboundLocalError: local variable 'c' referenced before assignment

Python2 f2py can run `f2py-2.7 -m foo -h foo.pyf breaksf2py.f90` fine, and python3 f2py can compile the resulting pyf file with `f2py-3.3 -m foo -c foo.pyf breaksf2py.f90`.

title: DEP: Deprecate the oldnumeric and numarray modules.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
The numarray and oldnumeric modules are deprecated. This is a bit tricky
as raising a DeprecationWarning on import causes an error when tests are
run. To deal with that, a ModuleDeprecationWarning class is added to
numpy and NoseTester is modified to ignore that warning during testing.

Closes #2905

title: min/max and base math vectorization
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
this pull includes the rest of the non-result changing float vectorization.
min/max is a little ugly as it needs to propagate nan efficiently. Are there platforms were fpu flag propagation is supported but NO_FLOATING_POINT_SUPPORT is set?

the base math is lengthy but simple, all the special cases are to archive optimal performance for these very common operations.

base math reductions are not vectorized as they change the results slightly (float add and multiply are not associative)

user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
Not decrefing it causes a major memory leak. This adapts the
automated tests to cover this case as well and adds refcounting
to it. Unfortunatly it makes the tests quite a bit slower. If
they get too slow, they could be marked as slow.

Thanks to Julian Taylor for noting the bug.

title: einsum crashes with default memory layout
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mrwojtek/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mrwojtek/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mrwojtek/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mrwojtek', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mrwojtek/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mrwojtek', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mrwojtek/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/4637806?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mrwojtek/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mrwojtek/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mrwojtek/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mrwojtek', 'type': u'User', 'id': 4637806, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mrwojtek/followers'}
body:
Using numpy version 1.7.1 the following code crashes: 
import numpy as np

A = np.ones(10000)
B = np.array([A, A, A]).T
T = np.ones((3, 3)) 

# OK
np.einsum('iq,ik,pk->ipq', B, B, T, order='C')

# Segmentation fault
np.einsum('iq,ik,pk->ipq', B, B, T)

body:
i386 does not have 16 byte long double by default (only 12 byte/float96)
so the import prevents numpy startup.
Introduced in 1.8.0dev 40000f508

title: ENH: Vectorize float absolute operation with sse2
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
fabs on x86 can be implemented by masking out the sign bit.
Obtaining such a bit pattern is best done by a bitwise not on the
negative zero.
This is the same operation the compiler will convert fabs to on amd64.

Improves performance by ~1.7/3.5 for float/double for cached data
and ~1.4/1.1 for non-cached data.

If one simplifies the loops gcc could also autovectorize it but with all
hints its almost the same code length and slightly worse assembly.

The code can easily be extended to support AVX by changing vpre and
vtype to 256.

title: ENH: Optimize array creation by avoiding errors
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/m-d-w', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/4601737?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'm-d-w', 'type': u'User', 'id': 4601737, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/followers'}
body:
This code optimizes numpy.array() when argument contains either list of lists or lists containing None.
These were problematic because exceptions are created and ignored causing significant (40x) overhead.

This optimization works by providing a 'lite' version of PyObject_GetAttrString which avoids creating exceptions
by special casing list, tuple and None types. Buffer operations are gated by PyObject_CheckBuffer.

Discused on stack overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16819261/why-is-numpy-array-is-sometimes-very-slow

#3396 - original version of this PR

#2938 - similar PR

title: SVD instructions: Example code has a mistake
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/anothermatthewmiller/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/anothermatthewmiller/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/anothermatthewmiller/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/anothermatthewmiller', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/anothermatthewmiller/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/anothermatthewmiller', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/anothermatthewmiller/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/4616164?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/anothermatthewmiller/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/anothermatthewmiller/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/anothermatthewmiller/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'anothermatthewmiller', 'type': u'User', 'id': 4616164, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/anothermatthewmiller/followers'}
body:
Wasn't sure to leave this here or scipy.

This url: http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.linalg.svd.html

Reconstruction based on a full SVD reads like this:
>>> U, s, V = np.linalg.svd(a, full_matrices=True)
>>> U.shape, V.shape, s.shape
((9, 6), (6, 6), (6,))

However, if full_matrices=True, then the shape of U is (9,9).  

From the parameters section: 
full_matrices : bool, optional
If True (default), u and v have the shapes (M, M) and (N, N), respectively. Otherwise, the shapes are (M, K) and (K, N), respectively, where K = min(M, N).

I was working through this and simultaneously trying to understand SVD, and this threw me for a loop when I could not execute this:

u, s, v = np.linalg.svd(a)
np.dot(u, np.dot(s,v))

This gives an error because the matrix dimensions do not align.

title: f2py support for MinGW-w64
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mwtoews', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/895458?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mwtoews', 'type': u'User', 'id': 895458, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.distutils', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.distutils'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.f2py', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.f2py'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Enhancement', 'color': u'e102d8', 'name': u'Enhancement'}]
body:
I'd like to build 64-bit Python extensions on Windows using the MinGW-w64 compiler, which provides gfortran. I've [explored this question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16929544/building-64-bit-python-extensions-with-f2py-on-windows), and it seems that much of f2py somewhat supports it with [a small hack](http://scientificcomputingco.blogspot.com.au/2013/02/f2py-on-64bit-windows-python27.html). The hack/fix is to pass and comment out `NotImplementedError("Only MS compiler supported with gfortran on win64")`.

I can then successfully compile an extension from `cmd.exe` using:
```
set PATH=%PATH%;c:\gnu\mingw64\bin

set C_INCLUDE_PATH=C:\gnu\mingw64\include

C:\Python27\python.exe C:\Python27\Scripts\f2py.py -c --fcompiler=gnu95 --compiler=mingw32 -m foo foo.f90
```
The resulting foo.pyd file works with the same version of Python ... success!

However, this is not yet feature rich, as I cannot seem to statically link in the GCC/gfortran components, as the resulting pyd file depends on 64-bit versions of libgfortran*.dll.

I'd like to package this Python extension to others without supplying these GCC DLLs.

I've tried using either `-static` or `-static-libgfortran` flags to one of either the `--f90flags=` argument, or the environment variables `FFLAGS` and `CFLAGS`. These don't seem to work for f2py, and I'm not sure why, even though I can confirm that the same gfortran compiler can statically build executables that do not depend on the GCC DLLs.

title: ma.empty/ones/zeros_like to copy mask properly
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tomyun/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tomyun/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tomyun/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tomyun', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tomyun/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/tomyun', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tomyun/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/906626?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tomyun/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tomyun/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tomyun/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'tomyun', 'type': u'User', 'id': 906626, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tomyun/followers'}
body:
As reported in #3145 and #2572, `ma.empty_like` does not copy, but merely assigns a reference to the original mask, leading to undesirable results.

This patch makes `numpy.ma.empty_like()` to work properly, in addition to newly introduced `numpy.ma.ones_like()` and `numpy.ma.zeros_like()`.

However, `numpy.empty_like()` and siblings still do not handle masks correctly. This could be a work demanding more lower-level changes.

title: String dtype inference/conversion broken recently
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
In NumPy 1.8. there is a regression probably caused by gh-3270 for string creation from objects types. I get bad results here on master for `np.array(12345678901234567890, dtype=object).astype(str)` which gives `array('12345678', dtype='|S8')`. Plus I just get a segfault for `np.array(123456789012345678901234567890, dtype=str)`.

I still think that we should maybe go through `PyArray_GetArrayParamsFromObject` -- or doing something similar -- and infer the dtype from the actual number/object length (which means adding object string length inference there), instead of this conversion size table.

title: np.array() very slow when args contain None or list of lists
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/m-d-w', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/4601737?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'm-d-w', 'type': u'User', 'id': 4601737, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/followers'}
body:
Discussed on StackOverflow here:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16819261/why-is-numpy-array-is-sometimes-very-slow

Details:

I'm using the numpy.array() function to create numpy.float64 ndarrays from lists.

I noticed that this is very slow when either the list contains None or a list of lists is provided.

Below are some examples with times. There are obvious workarounds but numpy.array() is very slow.

Examples for list of None:

### Very slow to call array() with list of None
In [3]: %timeit numpy.array([None]*100000, dtype=numpy.float64)
1 loops, best of 3: 240 ms per loop

### Problem doesn't exist with array of zeroes
In [4]: %timeit numpy.array([0.0]*100000, dtype=numpy.float64)
100 loops, best of 3: 9.94 ms per loop

### Also fast if we use dtype=object and convert to float64
In [5]: %timeit numpy.array([None]*100000, dtype=numpy.object).astype(numpy.float64)
100 loops, best of 3: 4.92 ms per loop

### Also fast if we use fromiter() insead of array()
In [6]: %timeit numpy.fromiter([None]*100000, dtype=numpy.float64)
100 loops, best of 3: 3.29 ms per loop
Examples for list of lists:

### Very slow to create column matrix
In [7]: %timeit numpy.array([[0.0]]*100000, dtype=numpy.float64)
1 loops, best of 3: 353 ms per loop

### No problem to create column vector and reshape
In [8]: %timeit numpy.array([0.0]*100000, dtype=numpy.float64).reshape((-1,1))
100 loops, best of 3: 10 ms per loop

### Can use itertools to flatten input lists
In [9]: %timeit numpy.fromiter(itertools.chain.from_iterable([[0.0]]*100000),dtype=numpy.float64).reshape((-1,1))
100 loops, best of 3: 9.65 ms per loop


# After patching:  was 240 ms, best alternate version was 3.29
In [5]: %timeit numpy.array([None]*100000)
100 loops, best of 3: 7.49 ms per loop

# After patching:  was 353 ms, best alternate version was 9.65
In [6]: %timeit numpy.array([[0.0]]*100000)
10 loops, best of 3: 23.7 ms per loop

title: np.array() very slow when args contain None or list of lists
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/m-d-w', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/4601737?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'm-d-w', 'type': u'User', 'id': 4601737, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/m-d-w/followers'}
body:
Discussed on StackOverflow here:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16819261/why-is-numpy-array-is-sometimes-very-slow

Patch files to fix this are here:

https://github.com/m-d-w/numpy-ctor-patch.git

Details:

I'm using the numpy.array() function to create numpy.float64 ndarrays from lists.

I noticed that this is very slow when either the list contains None or a list of lists is provided.

Below are some examples with times. There are obvious workarounds but why is this so slow?

Examples for list of None:

### Very slow to call array() with list of None
In [3]: %timeit numpy.array([None]*100000, dtype=numpy.float64)
1 loops, best of 3: 240 ms per loop

### Problem doesn't exist with array of zeroes
In [4]: %timeit numpy.array([0.0]*100000, dtype=numpy.float64)
100 loops, best of 3: 9.94 ms per loop

### Also fast if we use dtype=object and convert to float64
In [5]: %timeit numpy.array([None]*100000, dtype=numpy.object).astype(numpy.float64)
100 loops, best of 3: 4.92 ms per loop

### Also fast if we use fromiter() insead of array()
In [6]: %timeit numpy.fromiter([None]*100000, dtype=numpy.float64)
100 loops, best of 3: 3.29 ms per loop
Examples for list of lists:

### Very slow to create column matrix
In [7]: %timeit numpy.array([[0.0]]*100000, dtype=numpy.float64)
1 loops, best of 3: 353 ms per loop

### No problem to create column vector and reshape
In [8]: %timeit numpy.array([0.0]*100000, dtype=numpy.float64).reshape((-1,1))
100 loops, best of 3: 10 ms per loop

### Can use itertools to flatten input lists
In [9]: %timeit numpy.fromiter(itertools.chain.from_iterable([[0.0]]*100000),dtype=numpy.float64).reshape((-1,1))
100 loops, best of 3: 9.65 ms per loop


# After patching:  was 240 ms, best alternate version was 3.29
In [5]: %timeit numpy.array([None]*100000)
100 loops, best of 3: 7.49 ms per loop

# After patching:  was 353 ms, best alternate version was 9.65
In [6]: %timeit numpy.array([[0.0]]*100000)
10 loops, best of 3: 23.7 ms per loop

body:
Looking at http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/user/basics.types.html

The lower limit for int64 is missing the appropriate minus sign. The description for int64 should read "Integer (-9223372036854775808 to 9223372036854775807)"

title: ENH: linalg: Add an `axis` argument to linalg.norm
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/WarrenWeckesser', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/321463?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'WarrenWeckesser', 'type': u'User', 'id': 321463, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/followers'}
body:
Example:

    In [8]: a = array([[0,1,2],[3,4,0]])

    In [9]: a
    Out[9]: 
    array([[0, 1, 2],
           [3, 4, 0]])

    In [10]: norm(a, axis=0)
    Out[10]: array([ 3.        ,  4.12310563,  2.        ])

    In [11]: norm(a, axis=1)
    Out[11]: array([ 2.23606798,  5.        ])

    In [12]: norm(a, ord=np.Inf, axis=1)
    Out[12]: array([2, 4])

`axis` can be a 2-tuple:

    In [52]: a = np.arange(8).reshape(2,2,2)

    In [53]: a
    Out[53]: 
    array([[[0, 1],
            [2, 3]],

           [[4, 5],
            [6, 7]]])

    In [54]: norm(a, axis=(1,2))
    Out[54]: array([  3.74165739,  11.22497216])

This PR also fixes a bug that occurs when computing the norm of an integer array with a negative `ord`.  Before this change, `norm([1,3], ord=-1)` returned the incorrect value 1.0.  Now,

    In [13]: norm([1,3], ord=-1)
    Out[13]: 0.75

body:
I think I've found a memory leak in 1.8.0.dev-780d829. I'm using Python 3.3. The leak isn't present in numpy 1.7.1

```python
import numpy as np

n, p = 200, 60

y = np.random.random(n)
X = np.round(np.random.random(size=(n, p)), 1)

for it in range(10000):
    foo = X.dot(X.T.dot(X)).dot(X.T)
```

title: Inefficient memory and cpu usage by numpy ndarray operations
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fkbreitl/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fkbreitl/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fkbreitl/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fkbreitl', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fkbreitl/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/fkbreitl', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fkbreitl/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1030293?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fkbreitl/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fkbreitl/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fkbreitl/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'fkbreitl', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1030293, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/fkbreitl/followers'}
body:
When working with large 2D arrays, numpy runs out of memory very fast, probably because the memory is not used efficiently.
For example the following commands produce a "MemoryError":

    medians = np.ma.median(arr, axis=1)
    arr / medians

However, I can work around this problem by serializing the my operations with a for loop.
Moreover, only one CPU is used by numpy, although it should use all by default. So I had to code this all by hand as follows:

    def get_medians(spec):
        median_procs = []
        pool = multiprocessing.Pool(multiprocessing.cpu_count())
        channels = np.shape(spec)[0]
        for i in range(channels):
            median_procs.append(pool.apply_async(np.ma.median, (spec[i, :],)))
        pool.close()
        medians = np.ones(channels)
        for i in range(channels):
            medians[i] = median_procs[i].get()
        return medians

Numpy should do this by itself.
The same is true for multiplications and divisions:

    spec = spec * medians[:, np.newaxis]

title: Unaligned access
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
in gh-3309 I forgot to account for alignment of data, on cpus without unaligned access and the function receiving unaligned memory (not sure if that is possible though) it could crash.

To fix it I moved the byteswap functions to a header and check the alignment in ctors.c.
This has the additional advantage that some older gccs (e.g. gcc-4.4) are faster in the swapping loops as they now use the intrinsic.

title: numpy scalar * array-like == performance horror
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/inducer', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/352067?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'inducer', 'type': u'User', 'id': 352067, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/inducer/followers'}
body:
When I run this:

```python
import numpy as np

class MyThing(object):
    def __init__(self, shape):
        self.shape = shape
            
    def __len__(self):
        return self.shape[0]

    def __getitem__(self, i):
        if not isinstance(i, tuple):
            i = (i,)
        if len(i) > len(self.shape):
            raise IndexError("boo")

        return MyThing(self.shape[len(i):])

    def __rmul__(self, other):
        print "RMUL"
        return self
                      
print np.float64(5)*MyThing((3,3))
```

I get this:

```
RMUL
RMUL
RMUL
RMUL
RMUL
RMUL
RMUL
RMUL
RMUL
[[<__main__.MyThing object at 0x2298b90>
  <__main__.MyThing object at 0x2298bd0>
  <__main__.MyThing object at 0x2298c10>]
 [<__main__.MyThing object at 0x2298c50>
  <__main__.MyThing object at 0x2298c90>
  <__main__.MyThing object at 0x2298cd0>]
 [<__main__.MyThing object at 0x2298d10>
  <__main__.MyThing object at 0x2298d50>
  <__main__.MyThing object at 0x2298d90>]]
```

Is there a way to tell `numpy`, "no, don't worry about it, just call `__rmul__` on the whole thing, instead of picking it apart?"

In my specific case, `MyThing` is an array-like object that lives on a GPU, and while it's possible (and not necessarily incorrect) to pick the array apart in this way, it's unexpected and has *really* terrible performance.

(sorry about the many edits)

body:
From http://mail.scipy.org/pipermail/numpy-discussion/2013-May/066683.html

```
[Numpy-discussion] multivariate_normal issue with 'size' argument
Emanuele Olivetti emanuele@relativita....
Fri May 24 07:02:22 CDT 2013

Hi,

I'm using NumPy v1.6.1 shipped with Ubuntu 12.04 (Python 2.7.3). I observed an
odd behavior of the multivariate_normal function, which does not like int64 for
the 'size' argument.
Short example:
"""
import numpy as np
print np.random.multivariate_normal(mean=np.zeros(2), cov=np.eye(2), size=1)
print np.random.multivariate_normal(mean=np.zeros(2), cov=np.eye(2), 
size=np.int64(1))
"""

Which outputs:

"""
$ python2.7 mvn_bug.py
[[ 0.28880655  0.43289446]]
Traceback (most recent call last):
   File "mvn_bug.py", line 3, in <module>
     print np.random.multivariate_normal(mean=np.zeros(2), cov=np.eye(2), 
size=np.int64(1))
   File "mtrand.pyx", line 3990, in mtrand.RandomState.multivariate_normal 
(numpy/random/mtrand/mtrand.c:16663)
IndexError: invalid index to scalar variable.
"""

I had a brief look to the tracker but haven't found any mention of this issue.
It might be already solved in the current NumPy (v1.7.0)... or not.

I'd like to have your feedback before submitting this issue to the bug tracking 
system.

Best,

Emanuele
```

title: Fix version parse error from a personal build of GCC
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mwtoews', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/895458?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mwtoews', 'type': u'User', 'id': 895458, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mwtoews/followers'}
body:
I tried using GCC from this source http://sourceforge.net/projects/mingw-w64/files/Toolchains%20targetting%20Win64/Personal%20Builds/rubenvb/

which has a version string:
```
GNU Fortran (rubenvb-4.8.0) 4.8.0
```

This was incorrectly determined a version ``-4.8.0``, and added ``-mno-cygwin`` to the compile flags, which are no longer accepted.

See related: http://cens.ioc.ee/pipermail/f2py-users/2010-October/002092.html

title: BUG: ma: Inconsistent return type from the 'count' method.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/WarrenWeckesser', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/321463?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'WarrenWeckesser', 'type': u'User', 'id': 321463, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.ma', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.ma'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Easy%20Fix', 'color': u'02e10c', 'name': u'Easy Fix'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20normal', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: normal'}]
body:
Example:

    In [6]: a = ma.masked_array([1, 2, 3])

    In [7]: b = ma.masked_array([1, 2, 3], mask=False)

    In [8]: a
    Out[8]: 
    masked_array(data = [1 2 3],
                 mask = False,
           fill_value = 999999)

    In [9]: b
    Out[9]: 
    masked_array(data = [1 2 3],
                 mask = [False False False],
           fill_value = 999999)

Notice the difference: `a.mask` is the scalar value `False`, while `b.mask` is an array:

    In [10]: a.mask
    Out[10]: False

    In [11]: b.mask
    Out[11]: array([False, False, False], dtype=bool)

That's not the problem.  They both represent the same data: a 1-D array with the values [1, 2, 3], with none of the values masked.

Because these represent the same data, I would expect the `count` method for these two arrays to return *exactly* the same thing. However,

    In [12]: a.count(axis=0)  # Returns an integer
    Out[12]: 3

    In [13]: b.count(axis=0)  # Returns a scalar array
    Out[13]: array(3)

While the different return values act similarly in many cases, it is a nuisance (and a bug, in my opinion) that the return types are not the same.

title: BUG: ma: Several functions in the ma module return None when given a scalar.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/WarrenWeckesser', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/321463?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'WarrenWeckesser', 'type': u'User', 'id': 321463, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/WarrenWeckesser/followers'}
body:
Here's an example, using `ma.atleast_1d`:

    In [4]: np.__version__
    Out[4]: '1.8.0.dev-31a5501'

When given a scalar, the regular version of `atleast_1d` returns an array:

    In [5]: x = np.atleast_1d(1.0)

    In [6]: x
    Out[6]: array([ 1.])

`ma.atleast_1d` returns `None`:

    In [7]: x = np.ma.atleast_1d(1.0)

    In [8]: print x
    None

`ma.atleast_1d` and several other functions in the `ma` module are defined using the class `_fromnxfunction` (defined in numpy/ma/extras.py). In the `__call__` method of this class, in the case where `len(args) == 1`, the code handles the cases where the single argument is an ndarray, a tuple or list.  If the single argument is not one of these, the code falls through to the end without returning anything.

The non-masked versions of these accept a scalar, so the masked version should too:

    atleast_1d
    atleast_2d
    atleast_3d
    diagflat

body: The current doc string for `numpy.asscalar` is incorrect. It says the input data type is preserved, but it's in fact always converted to a native Python type via the input's `item` method.

title: severe performance regression when slicing on memory map
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
in numpy 1.7 since commit 731cf3aaaa95c714361f4062e6929f5a324586cc slicing in memory maps is extremely slow due to the may_share_memory call in array_finalize:

```
import numpy as np
from numpy import memmap, float32
fp = memmap("test.dat", dtype=float32, mode='w+', shape=(50,60))

for i in range(100000):
    np.sqrt(fp[5:10])
```

numpy 1.7 with the overlap check:

```
time python test.py
real	0m8.415s
```

when just removing the check:

```
time python test.py
real	0m0.843s
```

title: add quickselect algorithm and expose it via partition
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/juliantaylor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/542663?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'juliantaylor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 542663, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/juliantaylor/followers'}
body:
As announced on the list (http://mail.scipy.org/pipermail/numpy-discussion/2013-May/066645.html) here my quickselect based partition code.
This pull request should be considered as work in progress, but I want to get some feedback on it before I clean it up.

A partition sorts the kth element into its sorted order and moves all 
smaller elements before the kth element and all larger elements behind it. 
The ordering of all elements in the partitions is undefined.

It is implemented via the quickselect algorithm which has average linear
complexity compared to a full sort that has linearithmic complexity.
The worst case is quadratic.

String selection is implemented in terms of quicksort which has the same
properties as a selection for now.

As first method median is implemented as a partition now.
Another method I'm aware of that profits is percentile.


The naming of "partition" might confuse C++ users, in C++ its called nth_element but I think partition is a good name, the C++ variant of partition (partition by a comparison function) would probably be slower than simply sorting the array.

Right now it only has one algorithm.
I think a worst case linear but much slower variant can be implemented by choosing the quickselect pivot via a median of medians algorithm, but I'm not sure about that and also doubtful if its worth implementing (you can always heap/merge sort to get O(nlog(n)) worst case)

title: ENH: Fix SyntaxError when matrix() is called with invalid string
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/leonnnn/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/leonnnn/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/leonnnn/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/leonnnn', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/leonnnn/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/leonnnn', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/leonnnn/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/36083?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/leonnnn/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/leonnnn/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/leonnnn/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'leonnnn', 'type': u'User', 'id': 36083, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/leonnnn/followers'}
body:
The numpy.matrix constructor uses eval(str.translate(table)) to convert
input strings to numeric matrix contents. str.translate(table) will
return empty string if str consists only of invalid characters, causing
SyntaxError in eval(). This is confusing, as one would expect an
exception like TypeError when trying to construct a matrix from invalid
input.

This fix makes sure eval() is only called if str is not empty.
Otherwise, TypeError is raised.

title: f2py executable script shebang
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cpelley/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cpelley/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cpelley/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cpelley', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cpelley/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/cpelley', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cpelley/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2071643?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cpelley/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cpelley/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cpelley/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'cpelley', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2071643, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cpelley/followers'}
body:
The f2py executable has a shebang which uses the default python, rather than the python it was compiled for.  This causes issues for deployment of numpy (+f2py) across systems which have different environments.

We are currently patching the f2py setup.py as part of our build process which eliminates this problem.

title: Incoherence in meshgrid documentation
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gbiavati/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gbiavati/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gbiavati/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gbiavati', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gbiavati/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/gbiavati', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gbiavati/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/4508477?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gbiavati/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gbiavati/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gbiavati/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'gbiavati', 'type': u'User', 'id': 4508477, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/gbiavati/followers'}
body:
In the meshgrid documentation is written:
____________________________________________
Returns
-------
X, Y : ndarray
    For vectors `x`, `y` with lengths ``Nx=len(x)`` and ``Ny=len(y)``,
    return `X`, `Y` where `X` and `Y` are ``(Ny, Nx)`` shaped arrays
    with the elements of `x` and y repeated to fill the matrix along
    the first dimension for `x`, the second for `y`.
__________________________________________

This makes the function the same of the matlab meshgrid, but in the formalism of Python the first dimension is row and the second colums, so would not be more logical to produce as output an "(Nx,Ny)" matrix?

It would be nice to introduce a switch option in meshgrid or add a Meshgrid function that will do this.

title: numpy.core.umath.multiply - TypeError, while executing numpy.var
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kelidas/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kelidas/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kelidas/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kelidas', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kelidas/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/kelidas', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kelidas/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1210450?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kelidas/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kelidas/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kelidas/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'kelidas', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1210450, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kelidas/followers'}
body:
Numpy 1.7.1

numpy.core.umath.multiply break execution of numpy.var (or numpy.std).

Where:
```python
import numpy as np

# zero-rank array or scalar
val = np.array(5) # or val = 5
print 'mean =', np.mean(val)
print 'var =', np.var(val)
```
Expected output:
```
mean = 5.0
var = 0.0
```

I see:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/kelidas/workspace_git/scratch/scratch/recursion/test.py", line 10, in <module>
    print 'var =', np.var(arr)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/numpy/core/fromnumeric.py", line 2693, in var
    keepdims=keepdims)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/numpy/core/_methods.py", line 83, in _var
    x = um.multiply(x, x, out=x)
TypeError: return arrays must be of ArrayType
```

It's not very clear to calculate variance (std) for one value (scalar), 
but I was expected the similar behaviour as in numpy.mean (or older version of numpy.var in numpy 1.6.1).

immediately if not running from an *svn* checkout), so I'm sure

title: Export randomkit functions from mtrand.pyd
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/cgohlke', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/483428?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'cgohlke', 'type': u'User', 'id': 483428, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/followers'}
body:
Numba.random relies on randomkit functions being exported from the numpy.random.mtrand extension. On Windows these functions are not available in the mtrand.pyd extension. See https://github.com/numba/numba/issues/177.
This PR was tested with msvc9 and msvc10 compilers on Python 2.6 to 3.3, 32 and 64 bit. Not tested with mingw/gcc.

title: Remove the msvc_on_amd64 function
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/cgohlke', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/483428?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'cgohlke', 'type': u'User', 'id': 483428, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/followers'}
body: Which `distutils/msvccompiler.py` bug is fixed by the `msvc_on_amd64` function? Numpy and other extensions build OK for me without this function on latest Python 2.6, 2.7, 3.2, to 3.3 using Visual Studio 2008 and 2010. The `Forcing DISTUTILS_USE_SDK=1` printed when importing numpy.distutils is annoying. The use of `DISTUTILS_USE_SDK` to build with the Platform SDK is documented at http://docs.python.org/2/distutils/apiref.html#module-distutils.msvccompiler. Why change the documented behavior?

1. Mention the 4 variants of min/max functions in each other's See Also sections, clarifying how they differ
2. Don't waste space describing both the min and max in the See Also, just list the name of the opposite function
3. Add note about not using amax for pairwise comparisons

title: Generalized ufunc inner1d problems with 1-element inputs
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jluttine/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jluttine/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jluttine/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jluttine', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jluttine/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jluttine', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jluttine/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2195834?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jluttine/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jluttine/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jluttine/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jluttine', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2195834, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jluttine/followers'}
body:
In these new linear algebra routines as generalized ufuncs, I think the following is a bug:

```python
>>> import numpy.linalg._gufuncs_linalg as gula
>>> gula.inner1d([[2]], [[1],[1],[1]])
array([ 6.,  6.,  6.])
```
The result should be
```python
array([ 2.,  2.,  2.])
```
as far as I understand. Also, the following is weird:

```python
>>> gula.inner1d([2], [[1,2],[1,2],[1,2]])
array([ 8.,  8.,  6.])
```
I'm not sure whether it should return an error because the last axes have different sizes or whether the answer should be
```python
array([ 6.,  6.,  6.])
```
In any case, these results seem bugs to me. Any help? Thanks!

title: ma.corrcoef bug
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kijoshua/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kijoshua/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kijoshua/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kijoshua', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kijoshua/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/kijoshua', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kijoshua/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/324730?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kijoshua/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kijoshua/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kijoshua/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'kijoshua', 'type': u'User', 'id': 324730, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kijoshua/followers'}
body:
The documentation states that the masked version is just like the regular version of corrcoef, just with handling of missing data.  But how it handles that missing data isn't obvious, and I'm getting unexpected results.

    import numpy as np
    x=np.array([1,2,3,np.nan,5])
    y=np.array([2,2.5,3.1,3,5])
    xm=np.ma.masked_array(x,np.isnan(x))
    ym=np.ma.masked_array(y,np.isnan(y))
    m=~(xm.mask|ym.mask)
    a=np.ma.corrcoef(xm,ym,ddof=0)[0,1]
    b=np.corrcoef(x[m],y[m],ddof=0)[0,1]
    print(a,b)

(0.74153834037860156, 0.98871778717146885)

What exactly is the masking doing here, and why?  A naive approach to handling missing data in this case (for me at least) would be to discard datapoints where either x or y is nan (result "b").  Yet the result of ma.corrcoef ("a") is quite far from that.

body:
Platform: win32, python 2.6 binary installer from python.org, numpy binary installer of versions given, mingw32 compiler (specified in distutils.cfg)

"easy_install ffnet" works fine with numpy 1.6.2; with numpy 1.7.0, it raises a SandboxViolation:
> Wrote C/API module "_pikaia" to file "build\src.win32-2.6\ffnet\fortran\_pikaiamodule.c"
> Fortran 77 wrappers are saved to "build\src.win32-2.6\ffnet\fortran\_pikaia-f2pywrappers.f"
> error: Setup script exited with error: SandboxViolation: open('C:\\Python26\\lib
s\\libmsvcr90.def', 'w') {}

I know distribution/setup tools are a little flavour-of-the-month, but I haven't seen a call that numpy.distutils is incompatible with easy_install now (ffnet still recommends easy_install).
