title: 2to3: Apply zip fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
In Python 3 zip returns an iterator instead of a list. Consequently, in
places where an iterator won't do it must be enclosed in list(...).
Lists instead of iterators are also used in array constructors as using
iterators there usually results in an object array containing an
iterator object.

Closes #3094

title: Deprecate non integer arguments
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
This is gh-2891 rebased (with slight modifications in mapping.c). So basically all things said there still apply. To wrap it up, this deprecates non-integer usage almost everywhere (which means strides, shapes, axes, indices, slices), by deprecating it in PyArray_PyIntAsIntp.

Also deprecates `__index__` for ndim > 0.

I did go a bit further and deprecated python bools, too. If this starts bugging someone, that should maybe be made indexing specific.

I guess this might still need some love. The deprecation tests are not too great, but when errors get replaced it needs to test both warning and error. And they change, because previously they raised DeprecationWarnings (as errors) and now these are usually replaced.

title: 2to3: Apply types fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
Python 3 removes the builtin types from the types module. The types
fixer replaces such references with the builtin types where possible
and also takes care of some special cases:

    types.TypeNone           <- type(None)
    types.NotImplementedType <- type(NotImplemented)
    types.EllipsisType       <- type(Ellipsis)

The only two tricky substitutions are

    types.StringType         <- bytes
    types.LongType           <- int

These are fixed up to support both Python 3 and Python 2 code by
importing the long and bytes types from numpy.compat.

Closes #3240.

title: 2to3: Apply nonzero fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
In Python 3 the `__nonzero__` class method is replaced by `__bool__`.
This only affects the MaskedArray class in numpy/oldnumeric/ma.py file
and the simplest solution is to provide both methods. I have my doubts
that the fixed up Python 3 version was correct or even tested, but I
think the current solution should work for as long as oldnumeric stays
in numpy.

Closes #3073.

title: 2to3: Apply renames fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
Rename sys.maxint to sys.maxsize when the Python version is >= 3.  This
change was made in Python 3 because all integers are 'long' integers and
their maximum value bears no relationship to the C type that int used to
represent. The new sys.maxsize value is the maximum value of Py_ssize_t.
This change has not led to any reported problems since the numpy 1.5
release.

Closes #3082

title: 2to3: Apply basestring fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
The basestring class is not defined in Python 3 and the fixer replaces
it with str. In order to have a common code base we define basestring in
numpy/compat/py3k.py to be str when the Python version is >= 3,
otherwise basestring and import it where needed.  That works for most
cases, but there are a few files where the version dependent define
needs to be in the file.

Closes #3042.

title: 2to3: Apply itertools fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
In Python 3 zip, map, and filter are all iterators, consequently the
itertools variants izip, imap, and ifilter have been removed and the
itertools fixer replaces them with the unprefixed names.

Because the places where the iterator variants are used in current look
like places where the iterator version might be useful, the approach
taken here is to define the prefixed versions to the unprefixed versions
for Python 3, but otherwise import them from itertools.

Closes #3233.

title: 2to3: Skip itertools_imports fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
No files are changed by the itertools_imports fixer so skip it.  What
the fixer does is rename imports of imap, ifilter, and izip to map,
filter, and zip since the latter are iterators in Python 3.

Closes #3234

title: 2to3: Apply the `numliterals` fixer and skip the `long` fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
The numliterals fixer replaces the old style octal number like '01' by
'0o1' and removes the 'L' suffix specifying Python 2 long integers.

Octal values were previously mistakenly specified in some dates, those
uses have been corrected by removing the leading zeros.

Simply Removing the 'L' suffix should not be a problem, but in some
testing code it looks necessary, so in those places the Python long
constructor is used instead.

The 'long' type is no longer defined in Python 3. Because we need to
have it defined for Python 2 it is added to numpy/compat/np3k.py where
it is defined to 'int' for Python 3 and 'long' for Python 2. The `long`
fixer then needs to be skipped so that it doesn't undo the good work.

Closes #3074, #3067.

title: 2to3: Skip `setliteral` fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
Setliterals are not available in Python 2.6. Because the current usage
in numpy is forward compatible with Python 3 there is no need to run the
fixer.

When Python 2.6 support is dropped the fixer can be run, but that looks
to be several years off. RHEL 6 with Python 2.6 was released in 2010 and
will run for ten years.

body: There are a number of deprecations that we expected would be finalized in 1.8, but that won't be, e.g. gh-596, gh-456, gh-294. We've bumped them to reconsider for 1.9, but we should run a grep over the source to make sure that we haven't left any behind any messages that say "Warning: blah balh will happen in numpy 1.8", and if there are any we should replace them with something more vague.

title: 2to3: Skip `funcattrs` fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
In Python 3 the func.func_name attribute is replaced by the
func.__name__ attribute. The only file affected by this is
doc/sphinxext/numpydoc/phantom_import.py, and there its use
is already version dependent.

Closes #3054.

title: 2to3: Skip buffer fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
The buffer object is replaced by memoryview in Python >= 3. The memoryview object has also been backported to Python 2.7. However, the only use of buffer / memoryview is in `numpy/core/tests/test_unicode.py`
and there it is already version dependent: memoryview is used if the
Python version is >= 3 and buffer is used otherwise.

Closes #3043.

title: Make np.savetxt(filename, zip(...)) work in Python 3.x
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/astrofrog', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/314716?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'astrofrog', 'type': u'User', 'id': 314716, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/followers'}
body:
In Python 3, the behavior of ``zip`` changed - it now returns an iterator instead of a list. Therefore, things like

```
np.savetxt(filename, zip(...))
```

and 

```
np.array(zip([1,2,3],[4,5,6]), dtype=[('a', int), ('b', int)])
```

don't work anymore unless one wraps ``list()`` around ``zip()``. This minor PR ensures that ``savetxt`` does work with the new ``zip()`` function, though I'm not sure how to fix the second case since that seems to be handled at the C-level, but I think that if the second could somehow be fixed, this would fix the first, because ``savetxt`` calls ``asarray``, which calls ``array``.

title: 2to3: Skip `future` fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
The `future` fixer removes the `from __future__ import ...` statements.
That is fine for Python 3, but we need to keep that statement if we are
shooting for a common code base for both Python 2 and Python 3.

title: Add generalized ufunc linalg functions and make numpy.linalg use them
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/pv', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/35046?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'pv', 'type': u'User', 'id': 35046, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pv/followers'}
body:
This is a followup to gh-2954 ([list of new commits](https://github.com/pv/numpy/compare/e7a54da...pv:linalg-gu)), which replaces numpy.linalg routines with the corresponding umath_linalg implementations, while preserving backward compatibility for ndim <= 2 inputs. The new code is all under numpy/linalg.

Numpy's test suite and those of Scipy, Pandas, and Nipy pass with these changes, so there probably aren't obvious problems with backward compat.

This PR doesn't add new functions to numpy.linalg, only replaces existing ones. That, and other things still to do are summarized in issue gh-3217.

title: MaskedArray.dot not considering mask?
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tkf/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tkf/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tkf/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tkf', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tkf/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/tkf', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tkf/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/29282?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tkf/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tkf/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tkf/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'tkf', 'type': u'User', 'id': 29282, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tkf/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.ma', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.ma'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20normal', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: normal'}]
body:
`masked.dot(other)` is equivalent to `numpy.dot(masked, other)`, rather than `numpy.ma.dot(masked, other)`.

```py
In [1]:
import numpy
a = numpy.ma.array([0, 1], mask=True)
b = numpy.ma.array([0, 1])

In [2]:
a.dot(b)
Out [2]:
1

In [3]:
numpy.ma.dot(a, b)
Out [3]:
masked_array(data = --,
             mask = True,
       fill_value = 999999)
```

title: 2to3: Apply `map` fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
In Python 3 `map` is an iterator while in Python 2 it returns a list.
The simple fix applied by the fixer is to inclose all instances of map
with `list(...)`. This is not needed in all cases, and even where
appropriate list comprehensions may be preferred for their clarity.
Consequently, this patch attempts to use list comprehensions where it
makes sense.

When the mapped function has two arguments there is another problem that
can arise. In Python 3 map stops execution when the shortest argument
list is exhausted, while in Python 2 it stops when the longest argument
list is exhausted. Consequently the two argument case might need special
care. However, we have been running Python3 converted versions of numpy since 1.5 without problems, so it is probably not something that affects us.

Closes #3068

title: Incorrect warning rasied by logaddexp2
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tylerhartley/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tylerhartley/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tylerhartley/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tylerhartley', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tylerhartley/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/tylerhartley', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tylerhartley/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2185282?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tylerhartley/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tylerhartley/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tylerhartley/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'tylerhartley', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2185282, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/tylerhartley/followers'}
body:
#### Issue
np.logaddexp2 raises a Warning:

    RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in logaddexp2

when provided with two values of `-np.inf`. While the correct value is returned (-Inf), this is inconsistent with other logarithms of 0 that return -Inf with no warnings. 

#### Reproduce
You can simply execute:

```python
np.log2(2**-np.inf + 2**-np.inf)  # this raises no warnings
np.logaddexp2(-np.inf, -np.inf)  # this raises an "invalid value" warning
```

even though those two calculations are identical. I am not sure how or why logaddexp2 is raising any different warnings than log2, since as far as I can tell it's just a wrapper for internal addition for log2. 

Obviously you could manually supress this error, but it's inconsistent. Can somebody with a better understanding of how these errors are raised make the quick fix?

title: Assigning a fill_value in masked array fails silently for wrong type
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hamogu/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hamogu/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hamogu/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hamogu', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hamogu/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/hamogu', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hamogu/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/498688?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hamogu/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hamogu/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hamogu/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'hamogu', 'type': u'User', 'id': 498688, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/hamogu/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.ma', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.ma'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20normal', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: normal'}]
body:
I try to assign a `fill_value` to a masked array. If it's the right type (e.g. an `int` in an array of type `int`), it works, but if I try to assign a `fill_value` of the wrong dtype (e.g. a `string` in an array of type `int`, it fails silently. I don't know if this is a bug or a feature, but I had expected a `ValueError` or something similar if the value cannot be broadcasted to the required type.

```
In [1]: x = np.ma.array(np.arange(3).reshape(3), mask=[[1, 0, 0]])

In [2]: print repr(x)
masked_array(data = [-- 1 2],
             mask = [ True False False],
       fill_value = 999999)


In [3]: x.fill_value = 'n.a.'

In [4]: print repr(x)
masked_array(data = [-- 1 2],
             mask = [ True False False],
       fill_value = 999999)


In [5]: x.fill_value = -99

In [6]: print repr(x)
masked_array(data = [-- 1 2],
             mask = [ True False False],
       fill_value = -99)
```

title: Possible memory leak in np.diagonal()
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/kwgoodman', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/299024?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'kwgoodman', 'type': u'User', 'id': 299024, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/followers'}
body:
On my computer this leaks memory on numpy 1.7.0 but not 1.6.2:

    In [1]: a = np.ones((500,500))
    In [2]: for i in range(10000000): a.diagonal()

Functions that call a.diagonal, such as np.diag() and np.trace(), will also leak.

title: 2to3: Apply `repr` fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
This replaces python backtics with repr(...). The backtics were mostly
used to generate strings for printing with a string format and it is
tempting to replace `'%s' % repr(x)` with `'%r' % x`. That would work
except where `x` happened to be a tuple or a dictionary but, because it
would be significant work to guarantee that and because there are not
many places where backtics are used, the safe path is to let the repr
replacements stand.

Closes #3083.

title: 2to3: apply `dict` fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
In Python3 `dict.items()`, `dict.keys()`, and `dict.values()` are
iterators. This causes problems when a list is needed so the 2to3 fixer
explicitly constructs a list when is finds on of those functions.
However, that is usually not necessary, so a lot of the work here has
been cleaning up those places where the fix is not needed. The big
exception to that is the `numpy/f2py/crackfortran.py` file. The code
there makes extensive use of loops that modify the contents of the
dictionary being looped through, which raises an error. That together
with the obscurity of the code in that file made it safest to let the
`dict` fixer do its worst.

Closes #3050.

title: argsort segmentation fault
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mvogelsb/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mvogelsb/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mvogelsb/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mvogelsb', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mvogelsb/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mvogelsb', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mvogelsb/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/613735?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mvogelsb/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mvogelsb/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mvogelsb/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mvogelsb', 'type': u'User', 'id': 613735, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mvogelsb/followers'}
body:
Sorting a large number of int64 numbers causes a segmentation fault for numpy 1.7.0:

    import numpy 
    from numpy import random
    N=5000000000
    id1=random.random_integers(2**31-1,size=N)
    id2=random.random_integers(2**31-1,size=N)
    id=id1 + (id2 << 32)
    index=numpy.argsort(id)

body:
Add `print_function` to all `from __future__ import ...` statements
and use the python3 print function syntax everywhere.

Closes #3078.

title: MAINT: Cleanup some imports involving reduce.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
Because reduce has been available in functools since Python 2.6 we
can get rid of the version checks we currently have before we import
it.

Also removes some reduce related skips in tools/py3tool.py. We were
already skipping the reduce fixer so this has no effect other than
cleaning up the code.

title: documentation, tests, and bugs in seterr behavior for integer types
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ivanov/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ivanov/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ivanov/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ivanov', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ivanov/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/ivanov', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ivanov/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/118211?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ivanov/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ivanov/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ivanov/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'ivanov', 'type': u'User', 'id': 118211, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/ivanov/followers'}
body:
this is a work in progress. it started off as a documentation improvement for the fact, currently captured in #593 that `np.seterr` does not affect error handling behavior for arrays of integers (although it does mostly work for integer scalars).

But in writing a test for this behavior (which I was intending to submit and mark as a KnownFailure),  I discovered two other bugs in the scalar handling. These examples assume that `np.seterr(all='raise')` has already been called.

1. Integer scalar underflow (for all int types) is reported as overflow. Here's a bit of misinformation - should be UNDER-flow, not overflow
```
    In [28]: np.int8(-128) - np.int8(1)
    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    FloatingPointError                        Traceback (most recent call last)
    <ipython-input-28-2b810c89b4d5> in <module>()
    ----> 1 np.int8(-128) - np.int8(1)

    FloatingPointError: overflow encountered in byte_scalars
```
2. int64 overflow is ignored  during multiplication
```
    In [14]: d = np.int8; i = np.iinfo(d); d(i.max) * d(2)
    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    FloatingPointError                        Traceback (most recent call last)
    <ipython-input-14-3822c5509024> in <module>()
    ----> 1 d = np.int8; i = np.iinfo(d); d(i.max) * d(2)
    
    FloatingPointError: overflow encountered in byte_scalars
   
Good, we also get errors for int16,  int32, but not int64
```
    In [17]: d = np.int64; i = np.iinfo(d); d(i.max) * d(2)
    Out[17]: -2
```

title: BUG: solve issue #2649.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/glimmercn/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/glimmercn/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/glimmercn/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/glimmercn', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/glimmercn/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/glimmercn', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/glimmercn/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1971138?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/glimmercn/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/glimmercn/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/glimmercn/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'glimmercn', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1971138, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/glimmercn/followers'}
body:
The issue is similar to ticket #473(http://mail.scipy.org/pipermail/numpy-tickets/2007-March/000773.html), multipliaction of a matrix and a
column-vector returns a row-vector. That solution is to convert 1d
array, list, tuple to matrix before multiplying. What causes #2649 is that
matrix will use dot function which is inherited from ndarray. My solution is
to use __mul__ function instead. It will throw an error when user try to
multiply a sqaure matrix and a 1d array. Test on Linux is done.

title: segmentation fault with numpy.place
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/julien-diener/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/julien-diener/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/julien-diener/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/julien-diener', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/julien-diener/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/julien-diener', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/julien-diener/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3593669?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/julien-diener/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/julien-diener/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/julien-diener/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'julien-diener', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3593669, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/julien-diener/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.lib', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.lib'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20normal', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: normal'}]
body:
Hi, 

On my install at least (see below), I append to find an easy way to make a segmentation fault:

```
a = np.zeros(3,dtype=object)
np.place(a,[0,1,1],[])
```

I understand this is not be the right way to set some elements of an object array to an empty list (sadly), but still it should probably not crash python

os: mac10.6
python: 2.7.3   - with ipython 0.13.1
numpy 1.6.2

title: numpy.distutils.misc_util.get_shared_lib_extension() incompatible with Python >=3.2.4 and >=3.3.1
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/Arfrever', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/656294?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'Arfrever', 'type': u'User', 'id': 656294, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Arfrever/followers'}
body:
Meaning of `SO` variable has been reverted in Python >=3.2.4 and >=3.3.1 from ".cpython-32.so" / ".cpython-33.so" to ".so". (`SO` variable also has been deprecated in favor of `SHLIB_SUFFIX` variable and is removed in Python 3.4.) NumPy should use new `EXT_SUFFIX` variable, which has value ".cpython-32.so" / ".cpython-33.so" / ".cpython-34.so".

See http://bugs.python.org/issue16754 and http://mail.python.org/pipermail/python-dev/2013-March/124817.html.

Error in test suite of NumPy:
```
======================================================================
ERROR: Failure: OSError (/tmp/numpy-1.7.1rc1/test-3.2/lib/python/numpy/core/multiarray.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/site-packages/nose/failure.py", line 38, in runTest
    raise self.exc_val.with_traceback(self.tb)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/site-packages/nose/loader.py", line 413, in loadTestsFromName
    addr.filename, addr.module)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/site-packages/nose/importer.py", line 46, in importFromPath
    return self.importFromDir(dir_path, fqname)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/site-packages/nose/importer.py", line 93, in importFromDir
    mod = load_module(part_fqname, fh, filename, desc)
  File "/tmp/numpy-1.7.1rc1/test-3.2/lib/python/numpy/tests/test_ctypeslib.py", line 9, in <module>
    cdll = load_library('multiarray', np.core.multiarray.__file__)
  File "/tmp/numpy-1.7.1rc1/test-3.2/lib/python/numpy/ctypeslib.py", line 131, in load_library
    raise exc
  File "/tmp/numpy-1.7.1rc1/test-3.2/lib/python/numpy/ctypeslib.py", line 128, in load_library
    return ctypes.cdll[libpath]
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/ctypes/__init__.py", line 428, in __getitem__
    return getattr(self, name)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/ctypes/__init__.py", line 423, in __getattr__
    dll = self._dlltype(name)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/ctypes/__init__.py", line 353, in __init__
    self._handle = _dlopen(self._name, mode)
OSError: /tmp/numpy-1.7.1rc1/test-3.2/lib/python/numpy/core/multiarray.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 4838 tests in 97.229s

FAILED (KNOWNFAIL=6, SKIP=1, errors=1)
```

Patch:
```
--- numpy/distutils/misc_util.py
+++ numpy/distutils/misc_util.py
@@ -605,11 +605,15 @@
     Linux, but not on OS X.
 
     """
-    so_ext = distutils.sysconfig.get_config_var('SO') or ''
-    # fix long extension for Python >=3.2, see PEP 3149.
-    if (not is_python_ext) and 'SOABI' in distutils.sysconfig.get_config_vars():
-        # Does nothing unless SOABI config var exists
-        so_ext = so_ext.replace('.' + distutils.sysconfig.get_config_var('SOABI'), '', 1)
+    if is_python_ext:
+        # EXT_SUFFIX in Python >=3.2.4 and >=3.3.1.
+        so_ext = distutils.sysconfig.get_config_var('EXT_SUFFIX') or distutils.sysconfig.get_config_var('SO') or ''
+    else:
+        # SHLIB_SUFFIX in Python >=3.2.4 and >=3.3.1.
+        so_ext = distutils.sysconfig.get_config_var('SHLIB_SUFFIX') or distutils.sysconfig.get_config_var('SO') or ''
+        # Fix extension for Python 3.2.0 - 3.2.3 and 3.3.0.
+        if distutils.sysconfig.get_config_var('SHLIB_SUFFIX') is None and 'SOABI' in distutils.sysconfig.get_config_vars():
+            so_ext = so_ext.replace('.' + distutils.sysconfig.get_config_var('SOABI'), '', 1)
 
     return so_ext
 
```

title: f2py crashes with UnboundLocalError exception

body:
This is a copy http://projects.scipy.org/numpy/ticket/1932 since that one seems no longer in use and no one responded to it in almost 2 years, even though I posted a patch that solves the problem....

I have been trying to use the f2py routinely to build an interface around the ECMWF BUFR library. See http://code.google.com/p/pybufr-ecmwf/ for details. This works fine for the python 2.x versions.

However, I also tried to add the possibility to use python3 and here I encountered some trouble. My python code converts properly to python3 using to 2to3 tool, but when I try to use the python3 version of f2py I encounter this error somewhere deep inside the f2py internals:

    File "/usr/lib64/python3.2/site-packages/numpy/f2py/crackfortran.py", line 2505, in crack2fortrangen

title: 2to3: Apply `imports` fixer.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
The `imports` fixer deals with the standard packages that have been
renamed, removed, or methods that have moved.

`cPickle`      -- removed, use `pickle`
`commands `    -- removed, `getoutput`, `getstatusoutput` moved to `subprocess`
`urlparse`     -- removed, `urlparse` moved to `urllib.parse`
`cStringIO`    -- removed, use `StringIO` or `io.StringIO`
`copy_reg`     -- renamed `copyreg`
`_winreg`      -- renamed `winreg`
`ConfigParser` -- renamed `configparser`
`__builtin__`  -- renamed `builtins`

In the case of `cPickle`, it is imported as `pickle` when python < 3 and
performance may be a consideration, but otherwise plain old `pickle` is
used.

Dealing with `StringIO` is a bit tricky. There is an `io.StringIO`
function in the `io` module, available since Python 2.6, but it expects
unicode whereas `StringIO.StringIO` expects ascii. The Python 3
equivalent is then `io.BytesIO`. What I have done here is used BytesIO
for anything that is emulating a file for testing purposes. That is more
explicit than using a redefined StringIO as was done before we dropped
support for Python 2.4 and 2.5.

Closes #3180.

title: What is an invalid value in a NumPy Array?
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robertmuil/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robertmuil/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robertmuil/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robertmuil', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robertmuil/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/robertmuil', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robertmuil/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/637885?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robertmuil/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robertmuil/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robertmuil/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'robertmuil', 'type': u'User', 'id': 637885, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/robertmuil/followers'}
body:
I apologize for the vagueness of this bug, but I do not know exactly how to summarize it, nor even if it really is a bug.

I have encountered arrays on which any arithmetic operation (e.g. `arr-1`) generates `RuntimeWarning: invalid value encountered in multiply` and **does not return any data!** Neither `NaN`s nor `Inf`s reproduce this behaviour, because arithmetic operations on such values are well defined (`NaN` or `Inf` respectively). 

I assumed this was the result of using uninitialized arrays (`ma.empty()`) - however, even after generating thousands of large (1000) uninitialized arrays with `ma.empty` and performing `arr-1` on them, I have yet to reproduce the behaviour.

So, the invalid value appears to be something very particular, and I have no idea where it comes from.

The reason this is important is because if these errant values exist in a *masked* array, the error and failure to return data also occurs **even if the invalid value is masked**.

Can anyone clarify this?

Many thanks.

Here is a pickle of an offending array:
```
cnumpy.core.multiarray
_reconstruct
p1
(cnumpy
ndarray
p2
(I0
tS'b'
tRp3
(I1
(I1
tcnumpy
dtype
p4
(S'f8'
I0
I1
tRp5
(I3
S'<'
NNNI-1
I-1
I0
tbI00
S'\xff\xff\xff\xff\xff\xff\xf6\xff'
tb.
```

And here is a minimal failing example that loads that data:
```
import cPickle

print 'loading data...'
iv = cPickle.load(open('invalid_value.pickle', 'r'))
print ' done: iv=%s.'%(str(iv))
print 'arithmetic on 1st element of array...'
#This will succeed:
iv[0]-1
print ' done.'

print 'arithmetic on array...'
#This will fail:
iv-1
print ' done.'
```

user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/asford/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/asford/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/asford/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/asford', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/asford/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/asford', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/asford/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/282792?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/asford/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/asford/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/asford/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'asford', 'type': u'User', 'id': 282792, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/asford/followers'}
body:
During call to `PyArray_scalar` a `PyVoidScalarObject` is created, and
it's `obval` field set to a newly allocated block of memory of the
correct item size. With a null `base` member, the subsequent call to
`copyswap` can not determine an item size and returns without copying.
Adding direct copy of input data if no `base` is provided, as no swap is
required.

Adding regression test for constructor and original pickle repro case.

Closes #1550.

title: BUG: Raise immediate error in ctypes.load_library when library is bad.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
This is a fixup of PR #475 due to JeromeRoy. The problem addressed is
that when multiple errors were encountered attempting to import a
library file, only the last one was preserved. The proposed fix is to
raise an error immediately when a file of the correct name fails to
import, and raise a later error if no file is found but no errors are
raised in the search.

Closes #474, #475.

title: allclose and assert_allclose use different defaults
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/toddrjen', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2272878?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'toddrjen', 'type': u'User', 'id': 2272878, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/toddrjen/followers'}
body:
numpy.testing.assert_allclose, at least from the documentation, seems to be equivalent to asserting allclose.  However, in practice the two are not equivalent, because they use different default arguments.  

Specifically, allclose uses default atol=1e-08, while assert_allclose uses default atol=0.

title: 2to3 apply import fixer
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
The new import `absolute_import` is added the `from __future__ import`
    statement and The 2to3 `import` fixer is run to make the imports
    compatible. There are several things that need to be dealt with to make
    this work.
    
    1) Files meant to be run as scripts run in a different environment than
    files imported as part of a package, and so changes to those files need
    to be skipped. The affected script files are:
    
        * all setup.py files
        * numpy/core/code_generators/generate_umath.py
        * numpy/core/code_generators/generate_numpy_api.py
        * numpy/core/code_generators/generate_ufunc_api.py
    
    2) Some imported modules are not available as they are created during
    the build process and consequently 2to3 is unable to handle them
    correctly. Files that import those modules need a bit of extra work.
    The affected files are:
    
        * core/__init__.py,
        * core/numeric.py,
        * core/_internal.py,
        * core/arrayprint.py,
        * core/fromnumeric.py,
        * numpy/__init__.py,
        * lib/npyio.py,
        * lib/function_base.py,
        * fft/fftpack.py,
        * random/__init__.py
    
    Closes #3172

title: order of items returned by boolean indexing and nonzero
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kgabor/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kgabor/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kgabor/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kgabor', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kgabor/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/kgabor', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kgabor/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1903641?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kgabor/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kgabor/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kgabor/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'kgabor', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1903641, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kgabor/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20Documentation', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: Documentation'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20low', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: low'}]
body:
What is the order of elements returned by boolean indexing? In other words, what are the order of indices returned by nonzero? (Are they always sorted in the 1-D case?)  The order should be mentioned in the docs.

If 
```python
    A=np.array([[5,6],[7,8]])
    flag=np.array([[True,True],[True,False]])
```
then the result of A[flag] always looks to be [5,6,7] even if A is created with order='F'. I guess the order is actually inherited from flatiter that says "Iteration is done in C-contiguous style, with the last index varying the fastest." but this should be confirmed.

title: segmentation fault with numpy.array() from bytearray
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/megies/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/megies/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/megies/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/megies', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/megies/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/megies', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/megies/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1842780?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/megies/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/megies/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/megies/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'megies', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1842780, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/megies/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.core', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.core'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20normal', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: normal'}]
body:
I experience segmentation faults on certain systems when constructing a numpy array from a bytearray. The following code shows the problem:
```python
import numpy as np
bs = b'074906D SSB  00BH'
ba = bytearray(bs)
x = np.array(ba, dtype=np.uint8)
```
I am getting segfaults on these systems:
 - Python 2.6.6, Numpy 1.6.2, 32bit
 - Python 2.6.6, Numpy 1.7.0, 32bit
 - Python 2.6.6, Numpy 1.6.2, 64bit
 - Python 2.6.6, Numpy 1.7.0, 64bit

In contrast, the above example is running on this system:
 - Python 2.7.3, Numpy 1.6.2, 64bit

So it seems the problem is connected to Numpy's interaction with Python 2.6?

Using `np.frombuffer` instead of `np.array` works on all systems:
```python
x = np.frombuffer(ba, dtype=np.uint8)
```

title: `int64` range documentation has missing negative sign.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mdickinson', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/662003?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mdickinson', 'type': u'User', 'id': 662003, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mdickinson/followers'}
body:
From http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/user/basics.types.html :

```
int64	Integer (9223372036854775808 to 9223372036854775807)
```

That should presumably read:

```
int64	Integer (-9223372036854775808 to 9223372036854775807)
```

title: Segmentation fault when 'size' argument to numpy.random.multinomial has type numpy.uint32.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saffsd/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saffsd/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saffsd/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saffsd', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saffsd/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/saffsd', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saffsd/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/128034?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saffsd/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saffsd/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saffsd/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'saffsd', 'type': u'User', 'id': 128034, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/saffsd/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.random', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.random'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20normal', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: normal'}]
body:
Steps to reproduce:

Python 2.7.3 (default, Aug  1 2012, 05:14:39) 
[GCC 4.6.3] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import numpy as np
>>> np.random.multinomial(1,[0.5,0.5],np.uint32(1))
array([0, 1, 1])
>>> np.uint32(1)
1
>>> np.random.multinomial(1,[0.5,0.5],np.uint32(1))
array([0, 1, 0])
>>> np.random.multinomial(1,[0.5,0.5],np.uint32(1))
array([0, 1, 0])
>>> np.random.multinomial(1,[0.5,0.5],np.uint32(1))
*** glibc detected *** python: free(): invalid next size (fast): 0x0000000001bbfb90 ***

It also seems that numpy.random.multinomial behaves incorrectly when the `size` argument is of type `numpy.uint32` - in the above example, each vector is of length 3 whereas the expected behaviour is an array of length 2.

Some details about the platform:
>>> numpy.__version__
'1.6.1'

lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID:	Ubuntu
Description:	Ubuntu 12.04.1 LTS
Release:	12.04
Codename:	precise

uname -ar

title: ma.polyfit() returns nans when there are masked nans in the input
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/goyodiaz/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/goyodiaz/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/goyodiaz/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/goyodiaz', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/goyodiaz/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/goyodiaz', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/goyodiaz/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1676326?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/goyodiaz/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/goyodiaz/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/goyodiaz/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'goyodiaz', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1676326, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/goyodiaz/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.ma', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.ma'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Easy%20Fix', 'color': u'02e10c', 'name': u'Easy Fix'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20normal', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: normal'}]
body:
This used to return (almost) [1., 1.] but returns [nan, nan] in numpy 1.7.

    import numpy as np
    x = np.ma.array([np.nan, 1., 2.], mask=[True, False, False])
    y = np.ma.array([np.nan, 2., 3.], mask=[True, False, False])
    np.ma.polyfit(x, y, 1)

Changing the last line of ma.ployfit() this way seems to work for me:

    return np.polyfit(x.filled(), y.filled(), deg, rcond, full, w, cov)

But it does not make much sense to me, to be honest.

```
======================================================================
ERROR: test_exec_command.test_exec_command_stderr
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "X:\Python33\lib\site-packages\nose\case.py", line 198, in runTest
    self.test(*self.arg)
  File "X:\Python33\lib\site-packages\numpy\distutils\tests\test_exec_command.py", line 81, in test_exec_command_stderr
    exec_command.exec_command, "cd '.'")
  File "X:\Python33\lib\site-packages\numpy\distutils\tests\test_exec_command.py", line 12, in fake_with
    f(*args, **kwargs)
  File "X:\Python33\lib\site-packages\numpy\distutils\tests\test_exec_command.py", line 12, in fake_with
    f(*args, **kwargs)
  File "X:\Python33\lib\site-packages\numpy\distutils\exec_command.py", line 222, in exec_command
    use_tee=use_tee,**env)
  File "X:\Python33\lib\site-packages\numpy\distutils\exec_command.py", line 357, in _exec_command
    argv[0] = find_executable(argv[0]) or argv[0]
  File "X:\Python33\lib\site-packages\numpy\distutils\exec_command.py", line 126, in find_executable
    log.warn('Could not locate executable %s' % orig_exe)
  File "X:\Python33\lib\distutils\log.py", line 47, in warn
    self._log(WARN, msg, args)
  File "X:\Python33\lib\site-packages\numpy\distutils\log.py", line 31, in _log
    print((_global_color_map[level](msg)))
TypeError: 'str' does not support the buffer interface
```

The test passes when opening the TemporaryFile in ASCII instead of binary mode:
```
diff --git a/numpy/distutils/tests/test_exec_command.py b/numpy/distutils/tests/test_exec_command.py
index db37b6a..b7b60d9 100644
--- a/numpy/distutils/tests/test_exec_command.py
+++ b/numpy/distutils/tests/test_exec_command.py
@@ -76,7 +76,7 @@ def test_exec_command_stdout():

 def test_exec_command_stderr():
     # Test posix version:
-    fake_with(redirect_stdout(TemporaryFile()),
+    fake_with(redirect_stdout(TemporaryFile(mode='w+')),
         fake_with, redirect_stderr(StringIO.StringIO()),
             exec_command.exec_command, "cd '.'")
```

title: Why does __array_priority__ not take precedence over __array__?
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/astrofrog', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/314716?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'astrofrog', 'type': u'User', 'id': 314716, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/astrofrog/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.core', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.core'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20normal', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: normal'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Proposal', 'color': u'009800', 'name': u'Proposal'}]
body:
If I run the following dummy example:

```
import numpy as np

class MyCustomClass(object):
    
    __array_priority__ = 1000
    
    def __array__(self):
        return np.array([1,2,3])
        
    def __mul__(self, other):
        return np.array([4,5,6])
        
    def __rmul__(self, other):
        return self.__mul__(other)
        
c = MyCustomClass()
        
print(np.array([1]) * c)
print(c * np.array([1]))
```

I get

```
[1 2 3]
[4 5 6]
```

which in my view is incorrect (``__array__`` should not get called because ``__array_priority__`` is higher than that for ``np.array([1])``). If I remove the ``__array__`` method, I get the expected result:

```
[4 5 6]
[4 5 6]
```

as expected. This suggests to me that the presence of ``__array__`` takes precedence over the ``__array_priority__``. Is there a reason for this, or is it an oversight?

Most importantly, is there a way to get around this, and ensure that if ``__array__`` is present, ``__rmul__`` still gets called?

title: Revert changes to contiguous flags definition while creating NPY_TEST_UNSAFE_STRIDES
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
This (mostly) reverts the changes in the contiguous flags definitions. It does keep however some minor changes to make the current (lets call it safe) flags definition consistent for 0-sized, and 1-sized corner cases (which means that for these in some cases arrays previously considered contiguous are not considered contiguous anymore).

It introduces the NPY_TEST_UNSAFE_STRIDES build type enviroment variable to change the strides definition and make most new arrays be created with NPY_MAX_INTP as strides for dimensions with shape[dimension] == 1, to make bad assumptions in this case surface almost certainly while testing.

--

This needs documentation, but I think that can be addressed in a different pull request.

I have no idea about the building stuff, to be honest when I tested the code, I had some problems with using the enviroment variable and I edited the setup script itself, because it seemed it didn't pick it up, so someone please have a close look if there is something missing there (especially with different build methods, etc.)

title: New dtype behavior in numpy 1.7.0
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/kwgoodman', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/299024?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'kwgoodman', 'type': u'User', 'id': 299024, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/kwgoodman/followers'}
body:
Is this a bug (note the different dtypes of the output)?

    In [1]: np.array([1, 2, 3], dtype=str)
    Out[1]: 
    array(['1', '2', '3'], 
          dtype='|S1')

    In [2]: np.array([1, 2, 3]).astype(str)
    Out[2]: 
    array(['1', '2', '3'], 
          dtype='|S24')

This behavior is new to numpy 1.7.0 (and breaks some unit tests in one of my packages).

title: List of fixes that may be backportable
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
I thought there should be a bit of a list of things that might be worth back porting, so this is a start. It is the output from `git log master ^maintenance/1.7.x --no-merges --pretty=oneline  --abbrev-commit | grep BUG` (I guess grepping BUG does not cover everything though), minus those that already had a commit with the same commit message in the 1.7.x branch on march 19th.

I started removing some by hand, but not many yet as for many I simply don't know if they effect 1.7. at all. Please feel free to edit to remove unimportant or too complex ones and marking those that probably should be back ported (have started marking a few that I thought were good with "->", though not sure how much needs back porting).

```
23b87a5 BUG: fix NPY_NO_DEPRECATED_API mechanism.
0e4e508 BUG: Fix `not a in ...` to `a not in ...`.
a226daa BUG: Choose a more unique PY_ARRAY_UNIQUE_SYMBOL in f2py.
a3bc146 BUG: numpydoc: check that it works with sub-classes

title: MaskedArray.filled does not preserve array order
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jamestwebber/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jamestwebber/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jamestwebber/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jamestwebber', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jamestwebber/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jamestwebber', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jamestwebber/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/963647?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jamestwebber/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jamestwebber/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jamestwebber/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jamestwebber', 'type': u'User', 'id': 963647, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jamestwebber/followers'}
body:
Title says it all--I have an F-contiguous masked array (which I want for scikit-learn purposes) but as soon as I fill the masked values I get a C-contiguous version. This is because ndarray.copy defaults to C order and is [used by MaskedArray.filled] (https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/numpy/ma/core.py#L3449).

I believe fixing this simply requires changing that line to `result = self._data.copy('A')` and similarly for line 3444. As far as I can tell that's all of it.

(apologies if there is some reason for this behavior that I don't understand. If there is, I would be glad to hear it)

title: Nditer bug for multiple reduction axes
